Most people amongst the scene can attest that we'd see John nearly EVERYWHERE; from all the premiere events to lesser advertised events or performances that were supposed to be on the "hush" or the "hum bug".  A man of few words, and an avid lover of arts and music, John was always in the know….  Has captured many ground-breaking artists, musicians, innovators, singers, etc...
Just so happened, I saw John at Moods Music (one of the last independent music stores on the planet) just before my leaving for Washington, D.C.  During our quick, but meaningful chat, I asked John when he was going to have an exhibit. I also impressed upon the magnitude and importance of his photographic contributions.  John silently shrugged, modestly sharing that he’d not ever had a solo art exhibit, that he'd get around to it "one" day…  
When I returned, it was as if two puzzle pieces had come together; that John would be the photographer befitting to capture A Great Day In Atlanta, and A Great Day In Atlanta being the precursor and the catalyst to honor the work of photographic historian, John Crooms.
Now ten years later, having captured the original 2003 AGDIA photograph, and this year’s 10-year anniversary re-creation, we have come back to finish what we started; to give John Crooms a proper solo art exhibit!
Check out this article on the project - http://clatl.com/cribnotes/archives/2013/03/19/...


Here's the skinny...
As his first ever solo art exhibit, I want to make this special for John Crooms.  A Great Day In Atlanta (AGDIA) will be both and photography exhibit and installation.  With the inaugural A Great Day In Atlana photograph (2003) and the unveiling of the 10th Anniversary photograph (2013) being the foundation, AND YOUR HELP, we will tell the story Atlanta's renaissance through the work of John Crooms. I will use people in the photographs; their careers, works, past events, etc. as inspiration in what will comprise the actual photographs used in the exhibit. I will then incorporate multimedia aspects, captions, things that might be now be considered our artifacts in representing the people in the arts and music scene, pop-up performances, a nice reception and congratulatory toast...that being said, we need $8000, which will go towards: printing and mounting photographs

exhibit and installation materials
creating supporting multimedia components
securing props and artifacts
all aspects of the production
AND if we are lucky, we can print a select number of coffee table books 

***If by some small chance we don't reach our goal, we will most likely have to condense the number of photographs and/or portions of the exhibit, but we will still present a memorable exhibit of John Crooms work. Of course I am shooting for to complete our greatest vision!!! :-)
The Impact


Since the 1996 Olympics, Atlanta transformed into a performing arts mecca of the southern region and later in the early 2000’s the city was known internationally as the esteemed place for the entertainment industry to acquire talent. According to John Crooms: “In the late 80’s early 90’s Atlanta was really emerging and bubbling and it was a fresh new frontier that was happening. I felt I was a part of it and I wanted to be a part of it.” What we are seeing in today, is as a result of the innovative works of many of the creators, visionaries, pioneers, tastemakers and independant artists, many of whom are pictured in A Great Day In Atlanta. Through the lens of A Great Day In Atlanta, we experience a mirocosm of what is happening in art scenes around the globe. 
Just for the record, and so you know the passion behind my work, my last curation was the acclaimed photographic art exhibit/installation entitled Ministers Of Sound, which opened February 2013, featuring the work of photographer, Annette Brown. A unique tribute to DJ's, through the inspiration of my late father, Ministers Of Sound is a parallel and contrast of DJ's to ministers; modern day, indigineous  and/or spiritual leaders.  In this installation, the space was transformed into a sanctuary, with spiritual aesthetics; stained glass windows, the pulpit (which was the DJ booth), ushers, etc.  This ongoing exhibit received local and national coverage.  Here are a couple of the articles.
Creative Loafing Atlanta  - http://clatl.com/atlanta/ministers-of-sound/Con...
NBC's The Grio - http://thegrio.com/2013/02/25/photo-exhibition-...
 


Pockets a little thin? No worries, you can still help us make this project a reality!
You're not being able to contribute, doesn't mean you can't be apart of A Great Day In Atlanta...
HELP US SPREAD THE WORD...help us by posting on any of the social media outlets (Facebook, Twitter, etc.), send to your family and friends.  Also, Indiegogo has share tools too!!!

story:
Dear friends and strangers, 

Milda Books is so happy to announce the pre-sale of Paula Jansone's first book Seat 68. With this book we are inviting you to look at the recent historical changes in the region through the author's individual experience. In this deeply personal photobook Jansone travels with her grandmother to Madeira island. The trip was organised by a tour operator and the majority of the group members were seniors from Latvia. The adventure spirals into a miscommunication explosion culminating on the eve of grandmother's birthday, when all the generational differences come out in the open. Suddenly it is clear that they will not be able to find a mutual understanding on subjects like LGBTQ rights or climate change, the rest of the trip is a partly comical struggle to understand why we are different from each other and how to speak to each other. 
 



In the project the author talks about the intergenerational conflict between her grandmother, who grew up in the Soviet Union and herself - a young European who was born after the fall of the Soviet Union in free Latvia and was raised with democratic values.  At the centre of the series is the quiet and often invisible conflict between different generations. Two generations that grew up in opposing systems, with different accepted social norms and ideas what it means to be a human. Often what is acceptable to one, is completely unacceptable to the other.
 



Project Seat 68 aims to open the discussion about intergenerational conflict and to search for new ways for generations to coexist within one society. Currently, the polarisation of ideas is a problem. With social media, newspapers and leaders preaching increasingly what their own followers want to hear, it is next to impossible to get out of your own bubble. This project is an attempt to bridge the gap between generations and it is a quiet attempt to show the importance of truly listening to the other. Only through dialog we can come to an agreement. The polarisation will only lead to stronger division and if we want to survive all the current world’s problems we need to come together.
 



An early book dummy version of Seat 68

The photobook and its production

Paula Jansone worked closely with graphic designer Alexey Murashko to create a book design that would combine all the complex layers of this story - postcards, diary entries and present-day photographs. In the end, it's not only a beautiful object but hopefully a conversation starter for people to realise the importance of a dialog and truly listening to each other. The book will be produced in Swiss binding. The editor of the book is Valeriy Gorokhov.

Details about the book

First limited edition of 300

130 x 180 mm
Gloss laminated softcover with a foil and flap
Open spine Swiss binding
49 photographs
3 postcards from the family archive
128 pages

It will be published in November 2020
 



Paula Jansone's self portrait during the trip

Who we are

Paula Jansone (1993) is a Latvian photographer who has graduated from the ISSP School and analog photography lessons led by Andrejs Grants in Latvia. Prior to her work in photography, P. Jansone works as a project director in the field of culture and in education - she teaches Photography and video production at Latvian Culture College where she also filled in as the Head of Photography Department. Jansone has gained experience in writing prose, which helps to supplement her photography projects (Jansone's prose is published in several local bookazines and magazines). The author has studied the history of photography and also works with analog photography, creating experiments with film and the image. Jansone's photographs reveal a style in which the color contrasts, lights and framing plays a big role in the storytelling.

Alexey Murashko is a graphic designer and typographer. His works reveal a courage to experiment, and an admirable attention to seeming details. In the recent years Alexey has supplemented Latvian publishing industry with high-quality, well-thought-out and valued book design samples as well as witty visual identity works for cultural festivals and events. He have received certificates of Typographic Excellence from the Type Directors Club (New York) and the Tokyo Type Directors Club, as well as European Design Award in Gold and D&AD Wood Pencil, twice awarded with the title of Designer of the Year at the Latvian book art competition Zelta Ābele (Golden Apple) and many other nominations and recognizitions in the field of design and culture.

Valeriy Gorokhov is a photo director of online newspaper Meduza. Previously has worked for Snob Magazine and Russian Reporter Magazine.

Milda Books is a non-profit, non-commercial Baltic-based publisher of documentary photographers, visual writers, artists, and visual poets from the CEE region, founded in 2017. Milda Books produces one to three new books each year by contemporary artists, and also focuses on authors from abroad who have made their work within the Baltic region.

www.mildabooks.com
 



Why do we need your support?

This campaign is a pre-sale of the book that will cover the last remaining production costs of the book (printing and binding it) and shipping. All of us have previous experience working with photography books, both on an artistic and production level (printing, binding, and distribution). We're confident that our combined knowledge and skills will result in a quality book. After producing the book, we will be visiting festivals and book fairs, and we will send the book to an ever increasing list of photo book stores around the world to increase the visibility of the project after its launch.

We are planning for a production of 300 copies of the book. All together from translating the texts to designing the book and in the end printing it, amounted to €3500. Although we have managed to raise most of the funds needed, we are still missing €1500 to finish producing this book. That's why we are launching this pre-sale and asking for your support and contribution.

Indiegogo's platform fee on all funds raised is 5%. The book has already received support by the State Culture Capital Foundation of Latvia. 
 



Share

We understand that it's not possible for everyone to support our campaign, but we would be really grateful if you could share this beautiful story with your friends, family and through your social media. Thank you!

story:
My quarantine

STAY STILL, a photography book created during the first days of the pandemic lockdown by renowned cinematographer Xavier Grobet. 

The funds raised will go towards the book production. With your support and contribution, you will get our sincerest gratitude and a beautiful photography book carefully crafted by a great team in Barcelona, Mexico City and Los Angeles. 

Check out the perks menu on this page.

Please help us spread the word!

 

STAY STILL, un libro de fotografía creado durante los primeros días de la cuarentena por el reconocido director de fotografía Xavier Grobet.

Los fondos recaudados se destinarán a la producción del libro. Con su apoyo y contribución, recibirán nuestro más sincero agradecimiento y un hermoso libro de fotografías cuidadosamente elaborado por un gran equipo en Barcelona, ​​Ciudad de México y Los Ángeles.

Consulta el menú de recompensas en esta página.

Por favor, ayúdenos a difundir!

story:
Short Summary

Humanitarian photographer Emma O’Brien uses her images to tell stories of people who are often forgotten.  She has visited DRC twice in the last two years to meet with and photograph men, women and children living in Eastern Congo to document their stories with the aim of raising awareness and funds that will help to improve their lives.

Faces of Courage is a collection of portraits of ordinary Congolese people living in extraordinary circumstances   This campaign is about attracting funding to collate the images into a book, the proceeds from which will be used to fund education and women’s empowerment programmes in the Goma and Bukavu regions of the DRC.

It costs $75 to send a child to primary school for a year in Eastern Congo, $95 to send a child to secondary school for a year and $195 to provide one woman with a sewing machine and the tools to start her own business so she can provide for her family.  The sales proceeds from 500 books will enable 50 women to start their own businesses, 100 children to go to primary school and 80 children to go to secondary school. That’s 230 lives being directly changed with the help of your contribution, not to mention the impact these people will have on others around them, this may seem like an insignificant number but the ripple effect of something like this in a place where hopelessness reigns, is immeasurable.

Emma met with one lady whose family had disowned her after she had a baby at 17 years old, she was part of a sewing workshop in Bukavu to learn skills so she could start her own business in order to support herself and her child.  The impact of programmes like this is not only financial, it’s also a way of boosting self worth for people who have had their lives shattered by circumstances beyond their control.

What We Need & What You Get

Faces of Courage needs $19,000 for the printing and design of 500 books, this amount also includes budget for the marketing and promotion of the book to maximise sales and awareness of the project globally. As well as the creation of an online outlet for worldwide distribution of the book.

Donations of any amount are welcome and we’d like to offer the following as thank you for donations of specific amounts:

$50 – signed A5 print

$100 – signed A4 print

$500 – Signed A4 print and a mention in the book

$1000 – mention in the book and a personalised, signed copy of the book

If the campaign reaches less than 50% of the goal, all funds will be directly donated to HEAL Africa in Goma and ABFEK in Bukavu to use for their education and women’s empowerment programmes.  50% or more funds raised will be put towards printing as many copies of the book as possible.

The Impact

The key to helping people living in DRC have a better quality of life is education.  This project will benefit many people who would otherwise not have had access to schooling and skills to work their way out of poverty. The adage “Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.” Applies wholly to the purpose of this project.

 One of the missions Emma visited in Bukavu was a seed distribution programme.  The women on the programme described how the seeds give them hope for the future as they wait for them to grow and then reap the benefits of having food to feed their families as well as income from the food they sell.  This project is a means of planting a seed for the future of a better life in DRC.

Funds raised from the sales of the Faces of Courage book will be distributed equally between HEAL Africa and Action Kivu to be used specifically for paying school fees and sewing scholarship programmes.

The key to helping people living in DRC have a better quality of life is education.  This project will benefit many people who would otherwise not have had access to schooling and skills to work their way out of poverty. The adage “Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.” Applies wholly to the purpose of this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Emma works regularly in the philanthropic space within her community in South Africa on fundraising projects; she has photographed a calendar for Sandton SPCA for the last four years which has raised over $30,000.  In 2010 Emma put together a photography exhibition that raised $5000 for four local charities: Urban Vision, Child Haven, St John’s Academy and Love & Hope camp.

Please visit Emma's website to get in touch with her for more information about her work in DRC - http://emmaobrien.com

story:
Who we are and What we need!

We are 3rd year Commercial Photography students about to graduate from Derby University, UK.

We are exhibiting twice in the UK in a bid to get future work and promote ourselves.

Where & When? Derby University - 1st June - 13th June 2012

                     London Menier Gallery - 19th June - 23rd June 2012

**Please note: The video does say the London exhibition starts on the 18th but for unforeseeable reasons we have had to change this to the 19th.  Apologies for any inconvenience caused and we hope to still see you there!**

 

As we are sure you will all know, everything costs money these days and setting up an exhibition is no different.  We are aiming to raise $3,500 (around £2,200) which will help go towards things like:

  • Exhibition Space
  • Brochures
  • Flyers
  • Opening Night Refreshments etc
The competition for work in this industry is strong, so we are hoping that by showcasing our work in London we will put ourselves ahead of everybody else in securing future work and clients.  These exhibitions are really important to us and we would appreciate any money you could donate.
 
Alongside the IndieGoGo campaign we are also raising money in and around our local community. We have already held two successful parties, one for Christmas, one for Mardi Gras, and are looking forward to the raffle that is currently being organised.
 
We have a great range of perks that you can take advantage of, or alternatively donate the amount you can afford.

  

Other Ways You Can Help

We are only a small group of students and we would very much appreciate you spreading the word about our campaign in the hope that we can raise our full amount of funds and have a fantastic exhibition.

Check out our fantastic website showing all the exhibitors for each exhibition.
www.commphoto.co.uk

'Like' and 'Follow' us on Facebook and Twitter and tell all your friends and family about our campaign.

story:
What is Room with a View?

It began as a chance photography shoot, and turned into a hybrid photo book anthology. I have a life-long love of horror anthologies, and this one is loaded with fabulous authors, along with my photos of what the team from the Travel Channel's Ghost Adventures has called "one of the most haunted locations in Los Angeles": Linda Vista Community Hospital. These areas, as photographed, will never be seen like this again: the hospital complex is being completely renovated. The location has been featured in many movies, television, and paranormal investigation shows, and has a long and fascinating history. 

The project also appeals to my love of 'urban exploration' (abandoned sites, crumbling buildings) as, even in decay and neglect, beauty can be found. 

This project is dedicated to the memory and music of Dustin Randell Hiatt (February 9, 1987 - May 21, 2012). He had written a song especially for this project, which you can see on the preview trailer slideshow video.

Who are the creators?

Along with my photographs, many very talented, well-known horror authors contributed a wide variety of short, dark fiction, poetry, and everything in between.to this collection - inspired by the creepy images and fascinating history of the hospital.  

This impressive list includes:

Joe Pulver

John Palisano

Peter Giglio

Richard A. Becker

Marc Nocerino

Joseph Bouthiette Jr 

Ash Lomen 2

Vincent O'Neil 

Martin Reaves

Christian Hanner

Dustin Hiatt

Emanuel Shajhef Quinton

Edward Morris

Jim Earp

Allen Taylor

Tony Lovell

Sheri White

Alethea Cain

Tiki King

 

Please visit our Facebook page to learn more about the project, the photos and the authors:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Room-with-a-View/349239111791714

 

How will the money be used?

With successful funding, we will publish the hardcover and paperback editions of the book in Fall of 2012. It will 8.5" x 8.5 ", full color, at around 100 pages, featuring over 20 pieces of dark fiction.

We are seeking at least $7,000, which will be divided between:

 

contributing authors

printing/publishing costs 

contributor/review copies

marketing and promotionals 

 

Every little bit helps - please donate any amount you can. We thank you for your support! Feel free to spread the word, and check out the list of rewards to choose from!

What if we exceed our initial funding goal?

If we exceed our fundraising goals we will send an extra little 'thank you' gift to everyone who donated. We will also be producing related projects, like an audio book version and/or DVD project… check back for details!
story_txt:
What is Room with a View?
It began as a chance photography shoot, and turned into a hybrid photo book anthology. I have a life-long love of horror anthologies, and this one is loaded with fabulous authors, along with my photos of what the team from the Travel Channel's Ghost Adventures has called "one of the most haunted locations in Los Angeles": Linda Vista Community Hospital. These areas, as photographed, will never be seen like this again: the hospital complex is being completely renovated. The location has been featured in many movies, television, and paranormal investigation shows, and has a long and fascinating history. 
The project also appeals to my love of 'urban exploration' (abandoned sites, crumbling buildings) as, even in decay and neglect, beauty can be found. 
This project is dedicated to the memory and music of Dustin Randell Hiatt (February 9, 1987 - May 21, 2012). He had written a song especially for this project, which you can see on the preview trailer slideshow video.
Who are the creators?
Along with my photographs, many very talented, well-known horror authors contributed a wide variety of short, dark fiction, poetry, and everything in between.to this collection - inspired by the creepy images and fascinating history of the hospital.  
This impressive list includes:
Joe Pulver
John Palisano
Peter Giglio
Richard A. Becker
Marc Nocerino
Joseph Bouthiette Jr 
Ash Lomen 2
Vincent O'Neil 
Martin Reaves
Christian Hanner
Dustin Hiatt
Emanuel Shajhef Quinton
Edward Morris
Jim Earp
Allen Taylor
Tony Lovell
Sheri White
Alethea Cain
Tiki King
 
Please visit our Facebook page to learn more about the project, the photos and the authors:
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Room-with-a-View/349239111791714
 
How will the money be used?
With successful funding, we will publish the hardcover and paperback editions of the book in Fall of 2012. It will 8.5" x 8.5 ", full color, at around 100 pages, featuring over 20 pieces of dark fiction.
We are seeking at least $7,000, which will be divided between:
 
contributing authors
printing/publishing costs 
contributor/review copies
marketing and promotionals 
 
Every little bit helps - please donate any amount you can. We thank you for your support! Feel free to spread the word, and check out the list of rewards to choose from!
What if we exceed our initial funding goal?
If we exceed our fundraising goals we will send an extra little 'thank you' gift to everyone who donated. We will also be producing related projects, like an audio book version and/or DVD project… check back for details!

story:
Short Summary

Since 2018, I have curated Nowhere Diary on Instagram, spending hours and hours scouting the most amazing and unique photography out there.

The time has come to breath even more life into the world of Nowhere Diary and launch a website. A place for sharing even more incredible stories from photographers, featuring books on photography and inspire people of all ages with a passion for photography.

When I started Nowhere Diary in 2018, it didn't even exist. No hashtags, no posts, no nothing.

Nowhere Diary has since evolved into an amazing community of 284,000+ followers who engage daily with the stories and posts I curate. 

I have had the honor of featuring the work of such amazing photographers such as Todd Hido, Greg Girard, Paul Kranzler & Andrew Phelps, Maria Lax, Alys Tomlinson, Michael Lundgren, Jason Koxvold, Mark Mahaney, Tim Carpenter, Molly Matalon, Lorena Lohr, Kyle Thompson, Cody Bratt, Vincent Desailly, Shannon Taggart, Ward Long, Raymond Meeks, Jesse Lenz, Ron Jude, Richard Beaven, Nik Roche, Ken Light, Alessandra Sanguinetti, Guillaume, Tomasi, Arnaud Montagard, Justine Kurland, Maude Arsenault, Peter Watkins and many more.

 

 

I have accomplished this in many ways:

  • Consistently sharing the best photography out there.
  • Creating 'Nowhere Memories': Unique and incredible stories of photographers and their work. 
  • Creating 'Nowhere Newsletter': Weekly newsletter featuring the best in photography.
  • Featuring the best photography books - both from publishers and self published.

 

What I Need & What You Get

What I Need:

  • A website for Nowhere Diary.
  • Additional funds will be used to keep evolving Nowhere Diary.

 

What You Get:

  • Every contributor will be immortalised on the new website's supporters page no matter the size of your contribution.
  • The finished website will give you more features, resources, and inspiration than you can imagine.
  • More unique content to come in the future.

 

The Impact

In the 2 years of Nowhere Diary's existence, I have worked night and day to bring you the best photography and share your work no matter where you're from or how many followers you have.

Nowhere Diary is unique and unlike anything out there and best of all it is curated by a photographer.

And not just any photographer - a photographer with an endless passion for photography, a sparkling imagination and drive to tell your story and show your work.

Nowhere Diary is the first thing I think about when I wake up in the morning and the last thing I think about before I go to sleep - it has become me.

It is time to bring Nowhere Diary to the next level - and make a website.

The website will have all the stories and content of the Instagram but in a clean style true to the "Nowhere mood" and it will be much easier for users to navigate. 

A tonne of resources will be added to the site!

The site will also help to serve as a place for other photographers to showcase their work to the growing Nowhere Diary community.

 

Why I'm Asking For Help

  • I want to continue bringing you the best photography and I want to create the best website possible - for years to come.

  • I want to continue building a unique community for photographers, publishers, and followers of Nowhere Diary and I need your help to make this happen.

 

Risks & Challenges

Aiming to release the new website around the beginning of 2021.

  • Most of the content for the new website already exists. It just needs to be transferred to the new site once it's updated and live. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this campaign to anyone who loves photography!

 

All photos used in the campaign are copyright Filippo Giani

story:
Our Story

My name is Ben Earwicker. In 2005, my wife Michelle and I began to publish our body of international photography from the more than 25 countries we have visited, using the free-use photography site Stock Exchange.


As individuals, organizations, and businesses began to publish our work, we soon became the largest provider of free-use images on the site, and presently maintain one of the top 10 galleries on Stock Exchange. 

   


I am a Professor of Spanish and Latin American Studies, and use photography to communicate language and culture to my students and a larger online audience, through my research website, Garrison Photography, and our gallery on SXC.hu.

This May, I am taking a group of 20 students on a cultural, ecological, and photographic tour of Costa Rica. The photography produced on that trip will become a part of my expanding Latin America photo database, but only if I can raise enough financial support to fund the editing and maintenance of my online database and free-use photo archives.

The May trip to Costa Rica and all related expenses are already covered; this campaign will provide funding for the development of our free-use archives that are available to anyone online via our SXC gallery pages.


The Impact

This campaign builds on our work that has already been published and is available online for unrestricted use. The free-use photo database is open and accessible to anyone online, and our current images on SXC.hu have been downloaded nearly 2.5 million times!

The impact of your giving to this campaign can be measured by multiplying the usage of our current images by the estimated addition in photos that this funding will provide; if our current goal of $2,000 is met, we expect to publish a minimum of 1,000 free-use images from Latin America by August 2011. In other words, for each $2 we raise, we can support the publication of one additional image to our online database.

Without your support, thousands of uncut images languish in our digital archives, unavailable to the general public. Your generous contributions pay for the tedious process of selecting, editing, and cataloging images online.

   

What We Need & What You Get

Garrison Photography funds our administrative overhead and the initial costs of producing our award-winning photography. We seek additional funding this year to process and publish images from Costa Rica for online free-use and reproduction. All of the money raised through this campaign will pay for image editing and post-production costs, including online cataloging and publication.

As we approach or exceed our goal, we will also be able to support the publication of our existing stock photography from Latin America that has never been published online, including images from contemporary urban sites in Mexico City, Mesoamerican archaeological sites, and other settings, both urban and rural, in various Latin American countries. Even before the upcoming trip to Costa Rica, we have thousands of unedited images from Latin America that require post-production editing and online processing, all of which takes time and funding to accomplish.

For a donation of $10 or more, we will send you a limited-edition 4x6 print, signed and dated on the back. For a donation of $50 or more, we will also send you a limited-edition 5x7 print, along with a 4x6 print. Donors of $100 or more will additionally receive a signed 8x10 print.


   

   

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out! If you want to see more professional photography available online for free use, send your friends our way, and tell them about our campaign. You can use any of the social media features at the top of the page to share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, or any other number of sites. Thank you for your time and contributions.


We could not do this without YOUR support!

The expansion of free-use professional photography depends on our partnership through the CULTURA Latin America Project.

story:
My name is Julianne Cort. I am a senior at Ithaca College studying Film, Photography and Visual Arts. In my last semester, I am taking my photography thesis class, and I am looking to raise money in order to display my work at the exhibition that occurs at the end of the semester (In December 2012).
 
This project is an exploration in human nature. I find that the way people appear when they think no one is watching is intriguing. To isolate those moments is to capture people lost in themselves, unaltered by the self-consciousness that would arise from awareness of the creation of such an image. My goal in creating these images is to raise questions such as: What are these people thinking? What does this say about them as people? Can we relate to them?
 
I based this project off of a photobook I made last year. Here is a preview of it:  http://www.blurb.com/books/2786879
 
My estimated expenses are as follows:
 
Photo Paper/ Printing Costs: $135
 
Photo Mounting/ Finishing: $450
 
Transportation (to get to and from Media Finishings in Syracuse): $50
 
TOTAL: $635
 
 
Anything you can donate is much appreciated! Even just spreading the word about my campaign is a huge help!
 
And what do you get out of this? Swag! Check out the perks column to see what you could receive!
 
Check out my photo blog, which includes images from this project!
http://julianne-cort.tumblr.com/

story:
With a cult following already in San Antonio, Pierceology continues to provide professional photography so affordable it seems absurd.

 

PIERCEOLOGY A photography experience.

Pierceology is a simple, yet powerful business model that provides 2 hours of professional photography for $100. It truly is a photography experience! Your 2 hour session will include about 500 snapped shots. All of the photos are yours to keep and we even fully edit the best ones and upload to our Facebook Page. We shoot on location and for any request—engagement, wedding, modeling, food photography, real estate, commercial, senior portraits, reunions, sporting events—you name it! See some of our work at our Facebook Page.

You own all of the images with no copyrights, licensing requirements, or watermarks. We never up-sell and you are free to print or give away as often as you like. We know what the typical pricing can be for weddings, senior portraits, food photography, etc. We have proven, quite easily, that you can have fun while asking an honorable price—everyone wins!

In the past five months we have booked over 150 photo shoots and have over 1,000 Fans already on our Facebook Page! The purpose of our project here is to raise the money needed to buy two new macbooks, all new Adobe software and enough external hard drives to handle approximately 60,000+ photos annually (in the past 5 months we've saved over 25,000 photos)! Part of the remaining funds will be used to develop an app for us to use in which fans can schedule and pay via their smart phones and our scheduling can be completely automated. The last bit of money will be used to help secure a scheduler until our app goes live.

A successful campaign allows us to fulfill our vision of never having to increase our price above $100 for every 2 hours of professional photography, all while maintaining the integrity of what Pierceology is all about! 

We have some amazing perks to get you ready for your first (or second, or third...) Pierceology experience! Let's do this!

story:
About Exit Shows

I am a graduating senior at UGA in the photography department. Each semester before graduation, students earning BFA degrees put on an "exit show" to showcase their final body of work. This spring semester, it's my turn!

Since this is my last chance to exhibit at UGA as a student, it's important for me to make a lasting impression. 

With the right amount of funding, I will be able to exhibit my work in the most professional manner.

What I Need & What You RECEIVE!

Breakdown of Materials:
• (5) 24" x 36" Free-hanging, Back-lit, Single-Sided Light Boxes, each approx. $350
• 36" Vellum Photo Paper, two boxes, 150 feet $50

Perks!
• Donate $25 and RECEIVE an original 4x5 photographic print!
• Donate $100 and RECEIVE an origianl 8x10 OR (2) 4x5 photographic print(s)!
• Donate $500 and RECEIVE an original 16x20 OR (2) 8x10 photographic print(s)!

If my goal is not reached, I still plan to use the funding for my framing expenses, although, without this funding, it will not be as high-quality as the materials listed above.

Your Impact as a Supporter:

I've been an extremely dedicated and motivated student throughout my undergraduate career. With your support, I can raise the bar for my exiting exhibition. Top-notch framing materials will accent my work in a way that I simply cannot achieve on my own. Please contribute to my last hurrah at the University of Georgia and I'll be ever-so grateful for your help.

Can't Donate?

That's ok. Spread the word and make some noise about my final exhibition! Post on Facebook, email to your friends and family, tweet, tag, and pin!

 

Thank you.

Visit my online portfolio to view samples of my work and my curriculum vitae.
www.strawberrysquirrel.com

story:
What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise a total of £3,000. This money will primarily go towards paying for the exhibition space (alongside contributions from the University and ourselves), and materials, framing etc. 

    The Impact

    The show represents a culmination of three years of consistent hard work and dedication towards our craft as photographers. 

    As a team we will be responsible for designing, setting up and curating the exhibition space. It is extremely important to make this show happen for all us, as it’s an exciting platform to show our work to a large audience and many great future opportunities are born out of exhibitions such as this one. 

     

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you're unable to donate, you can still help just by letting people know about the show! Please share this page with all of your friends, and we hope to see you all there. You can also follow our social media pages for more updates about the show and our progress:

      Facebook: www.facebook.com/uowphotoshow17

      Instagram: www.instagram.com/uowphotoshow17

      Twitter: twitter.com/uowphotoshow17

story:
Two Lenses Focused Northward -

We are two young Montrealers who would like to show you Yukon’s reality as we will see it through our lenses. Aided by the magnificent images we will gather, we wish to present the daily lives of these people who are far away in terms of distance but who live in the same country as us.

We want to produce a testimony of the situation of Yukon’s inhabitants, all while creating a product worth exposing. Our objectives are to learn about the region, its history, and most importantly, how life is lived there and the stakes that must be faced.

Our exploration will be divided between a documentary, which will let the people and the images speak for themselves about the different Yukon regions, and a high quality photographic series which would portrait the people of the North.

Our expedition starts in Whitehorse, Yukon’s capital. We would then travel up North the territory, visiting many villages, some counting around 100 residents!

One of our goals is to travel north, beyond the artic circle et bring back footage from the more isolated communities of Fort McPherson et the village of Old Crow, Yukon’s only community with no road access.

We need your help to make this happen. You guys can help us finish our funding and will participate in a great artistic and cultural project!

Everything you donate will be used only for our project, whether it is to pay locals to help us once in Yukon, to buy food or to rent equipment to make our production better. Quality is our main concern and all your help will be put into producing the best quality project possible.

*The print rewards in the perks will be picked fron the magnificient images and portraits captured during our trip to Yukon.  In a few of months, after the project and the post-production are done, you will be able to select the picture you want after they are posted to our photographer's website:http://benjaminlamy.com/ -

 

Our deepest thanks in advance for your help! It will mean a lot to us!

 

Benjamin and Stefan

We are two young Montrealers who would like to show you Yukon’s reality as we will see it through our lenses. Aided by the magnificent images we will gather, we wish to present the daily lives of these people who are far away in terms of distance but who live in the same country as us.
We want to produce a testimony of the situation of Yukon’s inhabitants, all while creating a product worth exposing. Our objectives are to learn about the region, its history, and most importantly, how life is lived there and the stakes that must be faced.
Our exploration will be divided between a documentary, which will let the people and the images speak for themselves about the different Yukon regions, and a high quality photographic series which would portrait the people of the North.
Our expedition starts in Whitehorse, Yukon’s capital. We would then travel up North the territory, visiting many villages, some counting around 100 residents!
One of our goals is to travel north, beyond the artic circle et bring back footage from the more isolated communities of Fort McPherson et the village of Old Crow, Yukon’s only community with no road access.
We need your help to make this happen. You guys can help us finish our funding and will participate in a great artistic and cultural project!
Everything you donate will be used only for our project, whether it is to pay locals to help us once in Yukon, to buy food or to rent equipment to make our production better. Quality is our main concern and all your help will be put into producing the best quality project possible.
*The print rewards in the perks will be picked fron the magnificient images and portraits captured during our trip to Yukon.  In a few of months, after the project and the post-production are done, you will be able to select the picture you want after they are posted to our photographer's website:http://benjaminlamy.com/ -
 
Our deepest thanks in advance for your help! It will mean a lot to us!
 
Benjamin and Stefan

story:
Transitioning Cambodia will give you a unique insight into the contradictions of modern-day Cambodia. 

Over the past years, we have documented Cambodia's society as some embrace fast and sweeping development, while others struggle to keep up. This book is about the real Cambodia. It will feature the unique stories of groups and individuals who are living through this period of rapid change, may it be for the better or worse.

Transitioning Cambodia will combine images and text that illustrate these changes Cambodia has encountered by focusing on four key areas: 

  • Society and family
  • Land rights and development 
  • Modernisation and the emerging middle class
  • Youth and politics
Check out The Telegraph and the Asian Correspondent for a sneak peak.

Who we are

Nicolas Axelrod is a photographer who has been based in Cambodia for more than seven years. When he first got to Phnom Penh, Nicolas started documenting land disputes, which often led to forced and violent evictions and the relocation of already-impoverished communities on barren land. Before long, Nicolas widened the angle: Once the land was taken, what was happening to it? And who are the people the poor had to make room for? Nicolas' work didn't stop there. In projects that would last months, he documented how society was changing overall — from the traditional image of family to single mothers, from uninterested citizens to an engaged youth crying for political change. After seven years in Cambodia, Nicolas has produced an impressive body of work of tens of thousands of photographs — the best of which were selected for Transitioning Cambodia.

Denise Hruby is a journalist who first moved to Cambodia more than four years ago and has worked with both The Phnom Penh Post and The Cambodia Daily. As a freelance correspondent, she has written for international publications such as Al Jazeera, GlobalPost and the Christian Science Monitor. Her reporting has looked at the many aspects of development in Cambodia, and has earned her two journalism awards. From "bar girls" to sugarcane farmers, the stories of people's lives that Denise will tell will weave a narrative for Nicolas' photographs.

Fani Llaurado is a creative consultant and teaches design at Limkokwing University in Phnom Penh. She has been working in Cambodia for the last four years as a designer, photographer and lecturer. She will be doing the design and layout of the book. Fani has worked on the layout for several books and will make sure that the design and layout of Transitioning Cambodia will be perfect.

What We Need & What You Get

We are requesting US$8,000  to take Transitioning Cambodia to print. This will mostly be spent on printing 500 copies. A small portion will go towards writing the text and creating the layout, and to cover the costs for book launches in Phnom Penh and Bangkok, to which we'll invite you. 

Crowdfunding is our way of pre-selling the books. We hope to have sold as many copies of the book as possible before it goes to print. We are basically looking for a way to leave just a few copies in our hands for ourselves, while the majority will be shipped out to our backers across the globe.

Please check out our perks! Perks include copies of the book, the e-book, as well as photo tours around the places that will be featured in Transitioning Cambodia, with Nicolas helping you perfect your photography skills. The one-day or five-day photo tours will be catered to your needs; we will travel through Phnom Penh and the outskirts, learning about photography, storytelling and lots of background information on the areas we will visit.

If you have any questions regarding our perks, please do not hesitate to let us know.

Risks & Challenges

At this stage most of the hard work is done. The images are selected and edited, the basic structure for the text is done, and our designer Fani is working on the layout.

Now, our major challenge is getting the word out, pre-selling the books and taking them to the print house in Bangkok.  

If we don’t reach our goal of US$8,000, we will still go ahead and get the book printed. That means that no matter how many people back Transitioning Cambodia, you will still get the perks we've promised you for your contribution.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to support this project but do not want to do so financially, there are other ways to help. Simply use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word, or email a few of your friends to let them know about Transitioning Cambodia. We're thankful for every contribution.

Shipping

Please take these fees into consideration when contributing. If you have any questions do not hesitate to send us an email.
Thailand - Cambodia : Free
Southeast Asia: USD 5.-
Aus/NZ: USD 10.-
Asia and Europe: USD 15.-
USA: USD 20.-

story:
My Statement

Hello, there! I am Barbara Jewell, a BFA Photography student at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio. I specialize in dance portrait photography and performance photography. My artistic eclat, Lois Greenfield, is having her annual professional workshop in her New York studio. She is allowing a very select and small group of people to join her, use her photographic equipment (which includes her Hasselblad camera with a 22 megapixel-backing and professional lighting set up), and keep the images that they create. Here's a quote from her website:

"After demonstrating her process, the participants will photograph professional dancers at her studio in New York City using Broncolor strobes which stop action at 1/2000 of a second. Lois encourages the photographers to use her Hasselblad camera and the Leaf Valeo 22-megapixel digital back...The group is limited to 6-8 people... The cost for the two days is $1350."

After being in contact with her assistant for a month, I received a call from Greenfield herself explaining that she is holding me a place among professionals if I can make it to the workshop on from February 25th to the 28th. This is an opportunity like nothing I could have ever imagined. Being able to work with Greenfield would be an immense and invaluable step towards my professional career. And to get there, I need your help!


The Impact

This NYC workshop will be the foundation of my break into the professional world of dance photography. I will leave with professional insight into Greenfield's photography, make connections in my career field, and create a photographic portfolio epitomizing my goal as an artist. People are everything in the art world, and this workshop will supply me with an unparalleled contact book for an artist in my field.


What I Need & What You Get

I have written and received an $800 grant from the Dean of my college towards this project, but that covers less than half of my fiscal investment in making this trip to NYC from Ohio University in Athens. The itemized list is as follows:

$1,350 - Program fee

$300 - airfare

$475 - hotel reservations for the 25th through the 28th

$50 - transportation around NYC; to and from airports and Greenfield's Studio

-------------------------------------------------

= $2,225 total (I have not included emergency funding or extraneous costs)

(- $800 from my Dean)

(-$500 supplied by me)

= about $925 not covered!

I am trying to raise enough funding to cover the remainder of the program fee, which is due by the morning of the workshop on February 26th.

If you think you can't contribute much, please keep in mind that I would appreciate an $8 dinner at least for one of the nights!

For you, dear donor, I have perks for your gracious help in helping me to realize my dream! Since I am a photographer, I would be excited to exchange photographic services for any contribution to my trip; head-shots, performance documentation, dance portraiture, event photography, artwork documentation, basically anything you can think of, and I would be willing to work something out for your project. I also have access to studio space in Athens, OH but I could travel to document a specific event in the general area. Please reference my digital portfolio included in the links on this page for past projects.

Also, after the project I will be making a documentation of the trip and project as a whole. For $25 donors, I will include your name in the "Super Thanks" credits! Check out the other perks for donations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not in a position to support me financially, I would love for you to mention my NYC workshop trip to others. Please spread the word to every one you think would find this project interesting so perhaps they can help out. Notice the handy sharing toolbar on this page!

story:
I’m a 30-year old Photographer and this is my story of success and defeat:

My mother never liked taking pictures of herself and then when she died a couple of years ago, our family realized we only had 50 pictures of her whole life. That was the breaking point in my life, when I decided that my career of choice is going to be photography.

I became very passionate about learning everything there is about photography from the internet and everybody I knew, who were in some connection to photography. Soon I became an emerging star in commercial and party photography in Slovenia.  I got a steady job at a nearby club as their party photographer. But the nightlife and stress took its toll.

5 months ago I was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes (at the time I was weighing 124kg (273lbs) ) and that was my wake-up call that I have to change my life dramatically. If not for me, then for my 3-year old son, who needs to have a father in his life.  I went on a strict diet, started cycling and lost 30kg (66lbs) in the following months. But the night work stayed. Even though it is slowly destroying my health I can’t quit it, because I also have bills to pay. Therefore if I want to transition to commercial and fashion (daytime) photography I would need a studio. Here is where I need your help.

I did some research and found some nearby places that would be appropriate for a studio and rent for a suitable fee. The rent for a year would cost me 5000€  (6100$). In addition to the photographic equipment I already have, I would also need some strobe lights, a tabletop, a bunch of other small accessories and some simple furniture (a sofa, a desk for my computer for editing photos, etc.) I calculated that would be roughly around 4000€ (4880$) . Most important of all, this money would give me a huge head start in my studio-based photographic work. You can see my improvised home studio work so far on my website under Beauty and some under Concept. It is well worth noting that this shift in my career would have a immense positive impact on my health so I’m doing all I can to kick this plan into action.

I would also be very grateful if you could just share this campaign with your friends and family! Share it on Facebook, Tweet it, or just send a link to your friend. You help me so much, thank you. 

 

http://www.pro-car.si/portfolio.html

http://www.flickr.com/photos/56527506@N07/sets/

story:
First of all, sorry for my english.

My Story, My Project.

I'm an Italian Multimedial artist, 37 years old. The heart of my artistic research, are the forms of power. Politics, consumption, religion, economy, media, cities, social behavior. I am interested in the relationship between all these elements that form a single body. The Power.

Slaughterhouse - in italian Mattatoio - fits perfectly in this research. Bringing to light the "real price of meat" through the use of photography, in an aberrant trip, across the processes of industrial meat production. A process that dehumanizes men and beasts. A production line that everyone, including me, guiltily forget, even while the meat cooked, bleeds into our mouths.


The work, in short, is a trip through the slaughter houses that become a metaphor and truth of the dimension of power relationships.


As if to imply that the man who makes of the industrialization, the purpose of the report with the beasts, is available to translate in the same practices, in the relationship with the powers. In a bloody game, which makes humanity executioner first, then victims.

Moreover, the same relationship with the consumption of meat, always available, has disheartened our vision of coexistence of species. Now our look on the steak is the simple observation of a consumer good, that has just the cost of money. The same look of one who, knowing the size of his own power, looks at the nations, the masses, individuality.



The Impact

I am convinced that this photographic work, making public the practices of slaughter, will lead to critical consumption of meat.For a different relationship with power.


What We Need & What You Get

This Found Rising is required to bear the costs of production of the first exhibition. Production costs consist of the release of50 images (150 x 100 cm), the recording studio for the music that I composed for the show (a suite for cello, piano and vocals recorded During the course of the killing of animals), the production of the exhibition catalog.
The exhibition will be inaugurated in Cagliari, Italy, at the EXMA (a former slaughterhouse converted into an exhibition space)February 25, 2012 and ending March 30, 2012. From that day forward will be available ex for exhibitions around the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, Share this Found Rising. And share the Facebook event - http://www.facebook.com/events/335986769774470/ . All words of support will be appreciated.

story:
THE PROJECT

With your gracious assistance, I will be able to attend a nine-day photographic journey with one of the best photographers in the world--Detroit's Monte Nagler (www.montenagler.com).  On May 3rd, a very small group of photographers and Monte will pile in a van and leave Detroit, Michigan.  The first stop is in Cleveland, Ohio, then on to Niagara Falls and the Finger Lakes region in New York--with several other stops along the way.  The group will return to Detroit on May 11th--exhausted but ecstatic. Nine days of nothing but shooting and one-on-one instruction! 

THE GOALS

I have dabbled with photography since receiving my first camera--a Polaroid Swinger Land Camera--around the age of 12.  My first photos were of my family, friends and my cousin's cute boyfriend.  I have reached a point in my life where I want to quit "dabbling" and do something constructive with my photography. 

My three immediate goals are:

  1. Improve my photographic skills through more instruction on techniques and composition.  [Hence, my request for your help on attending this photo opportunity with Monte.] 
  2. Set up my own web page.  [I have just acquired www.lucindahuffphotography.com and will now coerce my son, Joshua, into helping set up my site.]
  3. Host a one-woman photo show at the Wesley United Methodist Church in Fostoria, Ohio.  I have a few photographs ready for the show, but need more to have enough to display.

Of course I have many other goals--but my end desire is to be proud and confident in my photographic skills so I can sell my prints. I have come a long way over the years since I first started shooting, but I am not in the home stretch yet!

I have been lucky enough to previously attend one of Monte's photographic trips.  Below are two waterfall photos--the first is a photo I took before I went on the trip with Monte.  The second was taken on the trip with Monte's guidance.  A little different, eh?

BEFORE MONTE

AFTER MONTE

WHAT I NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

The trip will cost $2,200 and will be paid to Monte Nagler.  This amount covers Monte's services, and all other trip expenses except food.  The additional $298 is to help cover a portion of the printing and mailing costs for the print(s) contributors will receive, and any fees due.  Any additional funds (I am the eternal optimist) would be used towards photographic supplies necessary for the trip. 

If I don't reach my goal, all funds will be forwarded to Monte as partial payment for the trip and I will sell some of my husband's "toys" when he isn't looking, to fund the rest of the trip.

After the photographic journey, I will select the ten best photos and give contributors their choice of print(s) as described in the Perks.  If you don't like any of them, then I can let you chose from other photographs I have taken.

BIOGRAPHY

Please, call me Cindy.  I am a 57 year old mom/grandma that is a marketing coordinator by day, and a photographer during my evenings, weekends, and vacations.  I have always had a creative streak, either through arts and crafts, sewing or drawing.  I inherited this from my mom, and the drive to learn new things and keep at it until conquered, from my dad.

Portrait photography and landscape photography have become the main focus of my energies, but I like to shoot all subjects.  I would like to think that I have progressed a lot since I started taking local adult education photography classes and weekend seminars whenever possible.  But I still need to improve my skills before turning this into something more than a hobby.

To date my successes include entering one photo contest, and winning second place in the open landscape category.  I have also shot a photo of the exterior of Terra Community College that was used in their published materials.  For a work-related trade publication, I actually shot the cover of one issue.  What a thrill!

I love photography--whether it is shooting, or enjoying others' work.  There is nothing like being transported to another place or time, or feeling a shift in my mood, from looking closely into a photograph.

THE CONCLUSION

Please check out the photographs on the Gallery Tab so you can be comfortable that I have some talent and you wouldn't be wasting your pledge.  I hope you believe in me and are willing to help further my education in photography and meet my goals.  This is something I love to do, and am a lucky person to be able to pursue my dream.  

Thank you for your consideration--and if you have any questions, please email me at lucindahuffphotography@gmail.com.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

If you can only provide emotional support (trust me, I understand!), then any help in letting your friends and family know about my campaign would be greatly appreciated.

shooting and one-on-one instruction!  THE GOALSI have dabbled with photography since receiving my first
camera--a Polaroid Swinger Land Camera--around the age of 12.  My
first photos were of my family, friends and my cousin's cute boyfriend.  I have reached a point in my life where I want to quit "dabbling"
and do something constructive with my photography.  My three immediate
goals are:
Improve
     my photographic skills through more instruction on techniques and composition.
      [Hence, my request for your help on attending this photo opportunity
     with Monte.] 
Set
     up my own web page.  [I have just acquired
     www.lucindahuffphotography.com and will now coerce my son, Joshua, into
     helping set up my site.]
Host
     a one-woman photo show at the Wesley United Methodist Church in Fostoria,
     Ohio.  I have a few photographs ready for the show, but need more
     to have enough to display.
Of course I have many other goals--but my end desire is to
be proud and confident in my photographic skills so I can sell my prints. I
have come a long way over the years since I first started shooting, but I am
not in the home stretch yet!
I have been lucky enough to previously attend one of Monte's
photographic trips.  Below are two waterfall photos--the first is a photo
I took before I went on the trip with Monte.  The second was taken on the
trip with Monte's guidance.  A little different, eh?BEFORE MONTEAFTER MONTEWHAT I NEED AND WHAT YOU GET
The trip will cost $2,200 and will be paid to Monte Nagler.  This amount covers Monte's services, and all other trip expenses except food.  The additional $298 is to help cover a portion of the printing and mailing costs for the print(s) contributors will receive, and any fees due.  Any additional funds (I am the eternal optimist) would be used towards photographic supplies necessary for the trip.  If I don't reach my goal, all funds will be forwarded to Monte as partial payment for the trip and I will sell some of my husband's "toys" when he isn't looking, to fund the rest of the trip.After the photographic journey, I will select the ten best photos and give contributors their choice of print(s) as described in the Perks.  If you don't like any of them, then I can let you chose from other photographs I have taken.BIOGRAPHY
Please, call me Cindy. 
I am a 57 year old mom/grandma that is a marketing coordinator by day, and
a photographer during my evenings, weekends, and vacations.  I have always had a creative streak, either through arts and
crafts, sewing or drawing.  I inherited
this from my mom, and the drive to learn new things and keep at it until
conquered, from my dad.
Portrait photography and landscape photography have become
the main focus of my energies, but I like to shoot all subjects.  I would like to think that I have progressed
a lot since I started taking local adult education photography classes and
weekend seminars whenever possible.  But
I still need to improve my skills before turning this into something more than
a hobby.
To date my successes include entering one photo contest, and
winning second place in the open landscape category.  I have also shot a photo of the exterior of
Terra Community College that was used in their published materials.  For a work-related trade publication, I actually
shot the cover of one issue.  What a
thrill!
I love photography--whether it is shooting, or enjoying
others' work.  There is nothing like
being transported to another place or time, or feeling a shift in my mood, from
looking closely into a photograph.
THE CONCLUSION
Please check out the photographs on the Gallery Tab so you can be comfortable that I have some
talent and you wouldn't be wasting your pledge.  I hope you believe in me
and are willing to help further my education in photography and meet my goals.
 This is something I love to do, and am a lucky person to be able to
pursue my dream.  
Thank you for your consideration--and if you have any
questions, please email me at lucindahuffphotography@gmail.com.OTHER WAYS TO HELPIf you can only provide emotional support (trust me, I understand!), then any help in letting your friends and family know about my campaign would be greatly appreciated.

story:
Photos of old Yerevan

HinYerevan.com is a map related photo collection of Old Yerevan. 

The site has contains more than 4,000 unique old photos (1890-2000) that are linked to an interactive map of the city.

Within two years of the site became very fond of among the old and new residents of Yerevan and guests of the city.

At the moment, we have decided to raise funds exclusively for the maintenance and further development of the non-profit project HinYerevan.com, which will continue to delight all lovers of old Yerevan.

story:
Hello and welcome to my campaign page!

I am Aurora; a creative and ever-learning 14 year-old photographer. I've always enjoyed taking photos, but a couple years ago, an awesome discovery of new friends and their art inspired me to become a true photographer...

I have a few friends (fellow ETUSC campers) who are amazing photographers! After we all got home from camp the year we met, we stayed in touch over the computer. In the months to come, I watched them grow as artists with this thing they were doing...this '365' project.

What is the "365 Project"?

A new photo taken each day for a year (and posted in Flickr as a means to share and grow)! I thought this was great because it keeps the photographer motivated to be working & improving on their skills everyday. I learned so much from viewing their daily additions that I decided I wanted to try it for myself! When my aunt offered to sell me her old camera (a Nikon Coolpix L110), I took her up on it, handed over my $100 birthday money and got started!

In the past, my subject matter was mostly nature; lots of macro focused flowers, plants etc., and I explored abstract compostions with blurred focus - but for this new 365 project, my friends were doing mostly self-portraits. Though I hadn't been very into that before, I saw that it could in fact be very creative & exciting! So, my photography became very much a blend of my old style & this newly inspired self-portrait style.

Some of my work:

I keep a selection of what I'm most proud of on my Flickr page - Please follow the link below!

http://www.flickr.com/photos/83463451@N08/

As I progressed, I started to have issues with the camera I had just used all my money to purchase:

  • There was no manual focus, so I couldn't experimint too much with specific focus, or the photo would end up looking plain bad instead of creative.
  • The photos were not sharp; this only improved a little bit when my mom got me a tripod.
  • I also hated the color-clarity (or should I say non-clarity!).
  • It also does not have video capabilities - which is something I would really like. (I've made some pretty cool movies in the past) 

Sadly, I only made it about 40 days into my 365, when I became just too frustrated with my camera to keep going.

My goal is to earn funds to buy my 1st DSLR camera!

I've thought of some great perks for my contributors, so please give them a look - You get the perk in your $ level, and also all the ones below that! I will create all the photographic perks (except for the pinhole perk) with my new camera.

I have already started saving (currently I've got $100) - but these cameras are expensive so I really need your help!

I am asking to raise at least $700 here on Indiegogo which will cover:

The Camera Itself:

  • A Nikon D3100, D3200, or maybe D5100 (My Mom's first SLR was a Nikon so it's in my blood to prefer them!)

A 3-Year Warranty:

  • Drops & Spills covered!

The Cost of Perks:

  • Purchasing supplies, printing costs, and postage.

and

Indiegogo Fees

Additionally,

If the campaign is successful enough to raise more than my goal (including my own savings), I will be able to choose some extra equipment...perhaps a remote control, cleaning kit, or maybe even a second lens.

and

My parents have offered to enroll me in a digital photo class if/when I raise enough money for my dream camera!

Thank you for reading about me and my passion! If you're able to help, that's amazing - and I'm so thankful!! But even if you cannot give $, you can help by spreading the word for me which is in itself super helpful!

Much Gratitude-

Aurora Corinne Jones

story:
Hello,

I would like to thank you for visiting my campaign. My name is Gabriela Tichá and I am 22 years old. I love traveling and taking photos when I am on my journey. I have already visited many beautiful countries, cities and places in Europe, Africa and Asia. This year I am planning to travel to Southeast Asia.

I have already visited some places in Singapore, Malysia and many places in Thailand but this time I have decided to make things a little different and I would like to offer you to take a part in my journey. Our adventure will start on 25th June and end on 25th July 2015. During this journey we will visit Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Koh Tao, Koh Samui, Ayutthaya and Bangkok.


Why I am doing his project

I am studying at Czech University of Life Sciences in Prague at Faculty of Economics and Management. I am in the second grade and I am writing my Bachelor's thesis on the topic  Electronic platforms for projects funding and creating this campaign will be part of my Bachelor's thesis. From this campaign I would like to cover my part of travel expenses for the journey which will be about 3000 USD.

About my project 

Everytime when I am traveling with people I love, it is a great fun and adventure and you can be a part of it through Twitter and Instagram. I am not flying from Czech Republic to Asia to spent four weeks on the beach, but I want to discover Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Koh Tao, Koh Samui, Ayutthaya and Bangkok as much as I can. I have already been in  Singapore, Malysia and Thailand but there are still too much places that I haven´t visited so I am returning back this year. In Singapore, Malysia and Thailand are some places which are such amazing, that you can visit them for a thousand times and you still will be amazed.

Please take a look at perks that I have prepared for you. You will find them on the right side of the website. I believe you will like them.

During my journey you will have an opportunity to watch my journey through Twitter (@travelfordreams) and Instagram(@travelfordreams). On Instagram I will be sharing with you photos from my phone and GoPro camera. High quality photos from Nikon camera and Panasonic HD Video camera will be used for your contributions rewards.

When I will return back home, I will spent from one to two months choosing best photos, creating video, writing my travel itinerary and sending all gifts and rewards to you.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can, please share this campaign with others. Tell your family and friends about it. Tweet about this campaign or share it with the world through social media. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools. It would help me very much.

Thank you so much in advance for your help. If you have any question, feel free to ask.

story:
Quick Summary 

My name is Kevin Serna and I am a photographer based in Chicago, Illinois. The purpose of this campaign is to create a space to pre-order as well as to assist in funding the creation of a photo book that completes a 7 year long project entitled La Presa. 

In La Presa I explore my relationship to my Father and in turn my own cultural identity by taking in the town in which he immigrated from in Aguascalientes, Mexico.

Featured on: Aint-Bad & It's Nice That

 

man on a brown horse on a red flower - special edition print, 11x17

 

Further Context

I take after my Mother, in mannerisms and language. She was raised as an only child in the U.S. by her adoptive parents, Marvin & Veronica. They were 1st and 2nd generation German & Dutch-Americans who were looking to settle down in small suburban town outside of Chicago and raise a family.

My Father and his brother were the first ones in their family to arrive in the U.S. during the late 70’s. They came from a very small mountain town called Presa de los Serna. La Presa, as it’s commonly referred to, is located in the central state of Aquascalientes, MX. After eventually landing in Illinois; my Father met my Mother and they decided to raise their family in the same house my Mother grew up in. 

Growing up in a mixed race house hold was confusing at times. I wasn’t sure why other friends weren’t going to their cousins quinceaneras like I was or why my tios and tias didn’t enjoy listening to Led Zeppelin like I did. I wasn’t sure why kids in elementary school noticed the differences in my facial features or why other Mexican children told me that I wasn’t Mexican.

Having never been taught Spanish by my Father, at times, I felt there was a disconnect between us as well as with my mostly Spanish speaking family. Still, we all loved and accepted each other and I gravitated further towards my Mexican heritage. However, for reasons I did not yet understand, on occasion, that acceptance had limits. My dad didn’t care to speak Spanish with me when I attempted and the things I wanted to do with my life and career didn’t always make sense to him when it came to giving support. 

On multiple occasions, verbal acts of prejudice that I witnessed towards my Father.. (a police officer who pulled my Father and Uncle over one night while I was in the car, a fellow student’s parent who didn’t like that my Dad wanted to video record a performance of a play I was in, a baseball coach who didn’t like that my Father was also a baseball coach) ..left me with a sense of anger and outrage, but also left me more defined in my cultural identity. That was, until small verbal acts of prejudice that I received for being white (gringo) from other Mexican students in high school came.

Throughout my life I have straddled this line between both sides of my cultural identity; never feeling like I was fully one thing or another. Most day’s I didn’t think about it. Why should I? You are what you are, I often told myself,  but defining my cultural identity has been both burden and joy and at the center of that conflict, I found my Father.

...

La Presa originally began as a simple creative exercise in 2010. My desire to capture the beauty of this town in Mexico, where my father grew up, is what drove me to make these photographs, but after I began asking him questions, I realized that my Father’s desire to show me the beauty of this place is what helped that original concept expand.

The town is rich in color and family history. Named after my family at its founding, I could see that my Father cared deeply about this place. 

Over the 7 year span of this project, I went back multiple times with my Dad to this town for 8 - 10 days each time. We would go on hikes or long walks almost every day during these trips. He would introduce me to friends from his youth, to family I didn’t know existed and to a history that I did not know I had. These memories and relationships that I was building with the people and family that live in La Presa are what gave me a feeling of ownership of that history and the sense of straddling a line dissipated as my Father and I shared in this experience.

 

Why a Book?

Shaping La Presa into a book format has elevated this body of work to it's strongest form. The story telling elements of tactile sensation, color, text and image layout that a book offers is what fully completes this series for me. 

 

Book Details

- Designed by Verena Michelitsch

- Printed by Conveyor

- 8x10 in

- 60 pages 

- Indigo Press, Smyth Sew, Hardcover Linen, Foil Stamp title, front, back and spine

 

Reason for this Campaign

- to provide people with a way to pre order the book and get perks that I am not currently selling anywhere else. 

- to help me mitigate the costs of creating this body of work which has spanned over 7 years via 7 - 10 day long trips almost every year to La Presa since 2010

- to help pay for book design fee's and to help me cover the first run of the book which will be somewhere between 150 - 200 editions.  

- to provide a space for people to just support the work if they like

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute - No worries! 

- You can help by sharing my campaign with others and spreading the work to anyone you think might be interested in it.
