Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute - No worries! 
- You can help by sharing my campaign with others and spreading the work to anyone you think might be interested in it.

story:
"Rather than coming here just to mourn, we should come with a great sense of dignity, a great sense of pride for what our ancestors accomplished." – Chris Schwarz

A tribute to Chris Schwarz

In June 2017, the Galicia Jewish Museum is planning to open a retrospective exhibition of the photography of Chris Schwarz, the founder and first director of the museum. This year marks the 10th anniversary of this distinguished British photographer’s premature death.

Before Kraków’s Kazimierz

Before devoting many years of his life to photographing traces of the Jewish past in south-eastern Poland, before permanently moving to Kraków to open the museum, for over two decades Chris worked as a photographer and photojournalist in Great Britain, the United States, Japan, Russia, Afghanistan and many other places.

Schwarz's work was always engaged, his lens often capturing those who needed help and attention the most, those who were often marginalized by society or those in power.

He documented social movements and the culture of capitalist society, Polish "Solidarity," as well as Afghan refugees in the 1980s. His photographs of the march organized by the National Front, and the opposition’s counter-march, which tried to block them, in London’s Lewisham were featured on the front pages of newspapers throughout the United Kingdom. He photographed the homeless in Paris and London, nursing home retirees, citizens of London's district of Hammersmith and fans of the Millwall football club. He spent countless hours watching and photographing theatre plays, art performances and other cultural events. His photographs were regularly published in various newspapers and magazines, e.g. Time Out, The Independent, Guardian.

Much of his work for British NGO’s was made pro-bono. As a photographer, he felt the urge to make his work meaningful and his photographs a tool for helping others.

Galicia Jewish Museum

Chris Schwarz devoted the last years of his life to the Galicia Jewish Museum. His powerful photographs, accompanied by texts from Professor Jonathan Webber, became the core exhibition of the Galicia Jewish Museum, which he founded and opened in 2004. He served as the Museum’s director until he passed away from cancer three years later.

"I arrived to Kraków on the 28th February 2004, my car loaded with computers and a giant Epson photographic printer – to confront a biting Polish winter, a large empty though renovated former furniture factory, some borrowed money and a dream to open a Jewish Museum. I had little Polish, no staff and no infrastructure. Seven weeks later the Museum opened."

When he was opening the museum, many predicted that it would not last even a few months. As the museum continues to thrive, he is remembered as a sensitive and determined visionary who left a deep mark on Krakow's district of Kazimierz.

The exhibition

The exhibition will focus on the amazingly rich and lesser known part of Chris Schwarz's photographic work. Most notably his documentary work from UK, his early 1980’s photographs from Poland, works from Afghanistan, Japan and may others. Working with his archives we were lucky enough to find number of Chris’ own vintage prints from 1980s, majority of which will be exhibited for the first time. The exhibition will open late June during Krakow’s famous Festival of Jewish Culture.

Your help

All those who knew Chris remember him as extraordinary person. Warm, kind and compassionate, but also one with bold ideas – he was a great driving force for projects which many would call impossible. This exhibition will be our (and hopefully yours) tribute to his life and work. During last few months we were researching his vast archives, scanning thousands of his negatives, spending hours and days discussing his work and his impact in Kraków’s Jewish district.

But we still need your help to secure funds needed to finish this exhibition. Although most of the research and curatorial work is now done, we still lack a portion of funds needed for production of the exhibition – mostly printing and framing the photographs according to high museum standards. This is, with no question, something that Chris and his work deserves.

In June 2017, the Galicia Jewish Museum is planning to open a retrospective exhibition of the photography of Chris Schwarz, the founder and first director of the museum. This year marks the 10th anniversary of this distinguished British photographer’s premature death.



Before Kraków’s Kazimierz
Before devoting many years of his life to photographing traces of the Jewish past in south-eastern Poland, before permanently moving to Kraków to open the museum, for over two decades Chris worked as a photographer and photojournalist in Great Britain, the United States, Japan, Russia, Afghanistan and many other places.
Schwarz's work was always engaged, his lens often capturing those who needed help and attention the most, those who were often marginalized by society or those in power.


He documented social movements and the culture of capitalist society, Polish "Solidarity," as well as Afghan refugees in the 1980s. His photographs of the march organized by the National Front, and the opposition’s counter-march, which tried to block them, in London’s Lewisham were featured on the front pages of newspapers throughout the United Kingdom. He photographed the homeless in Paris and London, nursing home retirees, citizens of London's district of Hammersmith and fans of the Millwall football club. He spent countless hours watching and photographing theatre plays, art performances and other cultural events. His photographs were regularly published in various newspapers and magazines, e.g. Time Out, The Independent, Guardian.
Much of his work for British NGO’s was made pro-bono. As a photographer, he felt the urge to make his work meaningful and his photographs a tool for helping others.



Galicia Jewish Museum
Chris Schwarz devoted the last years of his life to the Galicia Jewish Museum. His powerful photographs, accompanied by texts from Professor Jonathan Webber, became the core exhibition of the Galicia Jewish Museum, which he founded and opened in 2004. He served as the Museum’s director until he passed away from cancer three years later.
"I arrived to Kraków on the 28th February 2004, my car loaded with computers and a giant Epson photographic printer – to confront a biting Polish winter, a large empty though renovated former furniture factory, some borrowed money and a dream to open a Jewish Museum. I had little Polish, no staff and no infrastructure. Seven weeks later the Museum opened."
When he was opening the museum, many predicted that it would not last even a few months. As the museum continues to thrive, he is remembered as a sensitive and determined visionary who left a deep mark on Krakow's district of Kazimierz.


The exhibition
The exhibition will focus on the amazingly rich and lesser known part of Chris Schwarz's photographic work. Most notably his documentary work from UK, his early 1980’s photographs from Poland, works from Afghanistan, Japan and may others. Working with his archives we were lucky enough to find number of Chris’ own vintage prints from 1980s, majority of which will be exhibited for the first time. The exhibition will open late June during Krakow’s famous Festival of Jewish Culture.


Your help
All those who knew Chris remember him as extraordinary person. Warm, kind and compassionate, but also one with bold ideas – he was a great driving force for projects which many would call impossible. This exhibition will be our (and hopefully yours) tribute to his life and work. During last few months we were researching his vast archives, scanning thousands of his negatives, spending hours and days discussing his work and his impact in Kraków’s Jewish district.
But we still need your help to secure funds needed to finish this exhibition. Although most of the research and curatorial work is now done, we still lack a portion of funds needed for production of the exhibition – mostly printing and framing the photographs according to high museum standards. This is, with no question, something that Chris and his work deserves.

story:
THANK YOU ALL!

We'd like to offer a truly massive Thank You to everyone who supported our campaign - all of you are just the most awesome! 

We can't thank you enough - you've made this a truly special experience for both of us and we couldn't have made it this far without every single one of you, so truly: thank you. 

If you or someone you know would still like to pre-order a book, you can do so from our website here. You'll also find our prints and t-shirts there, so do stay involved and grab any goodies you missed in the campagin!

We will be in touch very soon with an update on timing for perk delivery. Thank you all again from the bottom of our hearts!

-----------------------------------------------

Ice Cream Headaches - Surf Culture in New York & New Jersey

We're raising funds to bring four years of travel, interviews, photoshoots and research to life in the form of a book. Welcome!

We are New York-based writer Ed Thompson (from England) and photographer Julien Roubinet (from France). We met surfing New York’s famous Rockaway beach, about an hour’s subway ride from Manhattan.

Over four years, we’ve driven up and down the coasts of New York and New Jersey to meet the 40 remarkable people who appear in the book. We’ve also documented more than a dozen epic hurricane swells that have landed on local shores.  

We’re asking you to join us as we turn the very best material we’ve collected into a beautiful coffee table book to preserve this wild adventure forever!


What’s in a Name?

The name Ice Cream Headaches reflects our surf experience. In the Northeastern US, the winter surf gets good but the water gets real cold... With modern wetsuits, we can still enjoy the ocean for a few hours, but when we duck-dive we often get “brain freeze” or “ice cream headaches” -- just like you might if you eat ice cream too fast. Everyone knows the feeling: something you love which occasionally kicks you in the ass (or brain)!

 

What You’ll Find Inside The Book

Surfers live in a paradoxical universe - the best surf spots are closely guarded secrets (hint: you won’t find any revealed in our book) and yet the culture is constantly on public display in fashion, art, film and music.

Our project peels back the layers: the craft and passion that goes into building surfboards by hand, the risks and fears surfers must overcome to make surfing a central part of their lives, and the dedication it takes to forge a pro career. It’s not always beautiful, joyful or easy, but surfing does offer huge rewards.

The book includes interviews with local legends like Tony Caramanico and Mikey De Temple, talented pros like Sam Hammer, Maddie Peterson, Quincy Davis and Balaram Stack, and surf culture luminaries like Pulitzer Prize winning author William Finnegan and photographer Michael Halsband. The interviews and swells we documented are supported by four compelling essays that take you beneath the surface of local surf culture: Surfers, Shapers, Stewards & Documentarians. 

Ice Cream Headaches will be published by Damiani Editore, an Italian publishing house specializing in art books and monographs. We're extremely lucky to be working with this talented and deeply experienced team, and we can't wait to get our hands on the book! Here are the specs: 

  • Hardcover 9" x 11" portrait format printed in gorgeous duotone
  • 192 pages, offset printed on heavy weight paper in full color
  • Spot varnished photos to protect them from UV damage
  • FSC certified, sustainably sourced paper from Italy

The details matter. We want to document the culture we love so much with care and passion. We're doing it for ocean lovers surfers today and those that will follow in future generations.

By supporting our IndieGoGo campaign, you can join this great adventure and become part of the story. We're truly grateful for your involvement!

 

Our Campaign

We could have made this book more cheaply and much faster by emailing people interviews and asking the community to send us photos and words for free. Call us old fashioned, but we decided to take the long road and make the book with 100% original sweat. We’ve covered all our own expenses including gas, tolls, camping fees, rolls of film and processing, not to mention countless unpaid hours, many late nights and even more early mornings. It's been quite a trip.

Now, to actually get the book into your hands, we need to pay for editing, design and some of the production costs (which we’re splitting with our publisher). We’ll also need to pay to ship our books to the US. The costs break down like this:

  • Editing: $3,000
  • Design: $5,000
  • Production: $6,750
  • Freight shipping: $900
  • Rewards: $2,950
  • Stripe & Indiegogo fees: $1,250
  • Total: $19,850
     


Radical Perks!

By buying one of our perks you can contribute to this creative adventure and show your support!

We’re super excited to share these with you - we think you’ll find something you dig in the links on the right.

  • Order your copy of the book today and you'll have it before it hits the shelves!
  • All prints are hand signed and numbered, archival quality and available in limited editions of 20, 15 or 10 (fewer editions for larger sizes). Print choices are 'first come first served'.
  • Only 50 copies of the Limited Edition book will ever be made. The limited edition book comes with a radical blue acrylic case, and an exclusive 8" x 10" signed and numbered print, only available to Limited Edition book buyers.  Get yours before they're gone!

Here's a sneak peak of the cover for our Limited Edition. The cover isn't finalized yet, but this is our vision for how it will look. Keep an eye on this page for updates and final designs!

And here's a little look at one of our limited edition prints you can scoop up with your copy of the book. Supporters who order prints will be contacted to choose the specific print they want at the end of the campaign. 

 

Environmental Impact

We’re ocean lovers, and we care deeply about the planet. Researching and producing a book comes at an environmental cost, so we’re donating 1% of proceeds from book sales to 1% For The Planet.

 

Risks & Challenges

The main challenges we face are failure to reach our target and delays with getting people their rewards. Delays are common with crowdfunding campaigns, but we’ve done our homework. We’re in good shape!

  • We’re under contract for our publishing schedule with Damiani Editore. The book will be available in Spring 2018!
  • We could opt to buy fewer copies of the book ourselves, reducing our share of production and shipping costs.

If we don’t raise all the funds, we’ll pay our editor and designer first because they’ve already done their work.

However, we’re 100% committed to funding our campaign. If we have to host a swim shorts car wash to make up the difference... so be it!

 

Why We’ll Succeed

  • This is Ed’s first book project, but Julien has already crowdfunded a book before - it’s a beautiful photo essay about car racing on the Bonneville Salt Flats!
  • We’re working with an amazing publishing house. Damiani have been incredibly supportive in helping us realize our vision. They work with talented artists and photographers all over the world, and the quality of their printing and production is world class.
  • Ice Cream Headaches will be distributed by DAP Art Books, who have handled notable surf titles like John Severson’s SURF and Yvon Chouinard’s California Surfing.
  • You can check out the quality of our work on our website.
  • You found us, right? So, with your support, we can turn this book into a reality! Thank you!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute to our campaign, no worries! You can still help us out MASSIVELY by sharing our story:

  1. Send this page to a friend who loves to be on the beach or by the ocean!
  2. Share this campaign with your friends and family on social media!

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

See you out there!

story:
Worum geht es?
Seit Juli 2018 arbeite ich an dem sozialen Kunstprojekt 80mm, das sich mit den Einsatzveteranen der Bundeswehr auseinandersetzt.

Es soll ein knapp zweihundert seitiges Buch entstehen und eine Ausstellung, in denen ca. 20 Einsatzveteranen mit Fotos und Interviews vorgestellt werden.

Das Anliegen des Projekts ist es, eine Diskurs anzustoßen, der die Thematiken der Einsatzveteranen in die Mitte der Gesellschaft bringen soll. Deshalb ist es mir wichtig, viele unterschiedliche Perspektiven zu zeigen und auch gegensätzliche Meinungen zu Wort kommen zu lassen.

Die Veteranen berichten über ihre Erlebnisse im Einsatz, ggfs. die psychischen Folgen und ihrem Umgang damit. Einige von ihnen leiden unter PTBS und sind teilweise nicht mehr arbeitsfähig, andere haben den Weg zurück in ein geregeltes Leben gefunden. Alle vereint, dass sie verändert aus dem Einsatz zurück gekehrt sind.

Wir möchten ein Bewusstsein dafür schaffen, dass es eine neue, junge Generation von ca. 400.000 Einsatzveteranen in Deutschland gibt. Das gesellschaftliche Bild eines Veteranen ist meist aber noch geprägt von dem versehrten Soldaten aus dem 1. oder 2. Weltkrieg.

 

Wobei brauche ich Unterstützung?
Mitten in der Produktion, nach vielen Gesprächen mit Unterstützern, Kritikern, den Protagonisten und Sponsoren, beginnt nun die heiße Phase, bei der ich Eure finanzielle Hilfe benötige.
Es geht aber nicht nur um finanzielle Hilfe, sondern auch Ideen, Kontakte, die Verbreitung und das Teilen von Posts im Internet sind wichtig, um möglichst viel zu erreichen.


Was ist das Ziel der Spende?

Druckkosten des Buches (mit Hardcover und Fadenheftung)

Prints für die Wanderausstellung (hochwertige Gallery Prints)


Dafür benötige ich 3000,- EUR inkl. Indiegogogebühr und der Steuer.

Letztendlich liegt es auf der Hand, dass je mehr Geld gespendet wird, das Projekt hochwertiger präsentiert werden kann.

 

Wer organisiert das Projekt?

Als freier Werbefotograf mit Fotostudio in Köln, kümmere ich mich mit einem kleinen Team um die Orga und Umsetzung. Dass ich selbst 8 Jahre bei der Bundeswehr gedient habe, in der Kombination mit meinem Kunststudium (Schwerpunkt Fotografie), motivierte mich nicht nur zu diesem Projekt, sondern macht auch vieles leichter.

 

Die Fakten

100% der Gewinne des Projekts, werden an gemeinnützige Zwecke mit Themenbezug gespendet (abzüglich Druck, Layout, Werbekosten, Fahrten, Verbrauchsmaterial, etc. Bei den Ausgaben wie Spesen, etc., richte ich mich nach Verrechnungssätzen von gemeinnützigen Organisationen).

Es ist ein von mir frei entwickeltes Projekt. Es gibt kein Schirmherr oder Auftraggeber.

Das Projekt hat politisch gesehen, weder eine linke noch eine rechte Ausrichtung. Es verhält sich der Bundeswehr gegenüber so neutral wie möglich.

Über jeden Einsatzveteran (ca. 20) werden sechs bis acht Seiten erstellt, auf denen zwei bis sechs Fotos, inkl. des Interviews zu sehen sind.

Hier ein paar Fotos der Protagonisten:
https://www.bracht-fotografie.de/portrait/einsa...

#projekt80mm

Mit erwartungsvollen Grüßen

Roman Bracht

(Kein Einsatzveteran, 2008-2011: 3. PzGrenLehrBtl 92, 2011-2012 Ev. Militärpfarramt Köln I, 2013-2018 BwFachSBetrSt Köln, Studium der Fotografie BFA in Essen)

 

Falls Du Fragen zu dem Projekt hast oder eine Idee, interessiert mich das sehr. Ruf einfach an unter 0176 - 22 33 48 41 oder schreibe mir eine E-Mail an r.bracht@bracht-fotografie.de. Besten Dank!

Studio 176 / Bracht

Vorgebirgstr. 176

50969 Köln

www.bracht-fotografie.de

 

Unterstütze auch hier:

Facebook www.facebook.com/brachtfotografie

Instagram www.instagram.com/roman_bracht

story:
What is SnapNation?

MOBILE PHOTO APP + CREATIVITY = DAILY COMPETITION

For those of you how thought there wasn't room for "another photo app" you are right...this will be a photo experience encouraging you on a daily basis.

Who Am I?

My name is Rudy Pollorena Jr and I was born & raised in San Diego, CA. I have been designing video games for the last 10+ years and now focused on SnapNation and building a team together to get this in full swing.

Goal wasn't met - where do we go from here?

Even though the goal has not been met, we will continue to move forward as aggressively as we can and seek the funds from investors. We believe SnapNation will enlighten and ignite the creativity from those around the world. Driven by competition and daily themes we will provide you a daily goal to capture the visual world around you.

We are now engaging with investors to make SnapNation happen!

Follow Us

We currently have a Facebook Fan Page: www.facebook.com/snapnationworld

Also, when you become fans of the facebook page we will send you an update for a newsletter for updates and possible beta tester signups!

Follow us on Twitter @snapnation www.twitter.com/snapnation

Thank You All!

Thank you all who have contributed, shared and expressed excitement for SnapNation.

This campaign has been a great learning experience and you all have helped spawn new ideas and insight on what SnapNation could become! We will take this feedback and help shape SnapNation further.

You will hear from us real soon :)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CREDITS

Trailer was Shot & Edited by Norman MacKinnon - See more of his work HERE

Music created by "I Hear Sirens" & d.C. from www.soulplusmind.com

Some icons shown the visual mockups are credited to: "Icons By Glyphish"


Any trademarks in this video are per their respective companies and copyrights

This campaign has been a great learning experience and you all have helped spawn new ideas and insight on what SnapNation could become! We will take this feedback and help shape SnapNation further.
You will hear from us real soon :)


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CREDITS
Trailer was Shot & Edited by Norman MacKinnon - See more of his work HERE
Music created by "I Hear Sirens" & d.C. from www.soulplusmind.com
Some icons shown the visual mockups are credited to: "Icons By Glyphish"

Any trademarks in this video are per their respective companies and copyrights

story:
Temples of Angkor - George Mann

The Angkor Temples project actually started in 1979 for me, while on assignment to the UNHCR, documenting the refugee crisis of post Vietnam War South East Asia. Since those days I have returned to Cambodia many times, mostly concentrating on the incredible temple ruins of the long lost Angkor Empire:

  • My background is mostly in commercial photography, working out of Bangkok and Los Angeles, since the late 1970s. I have also traveled fairly widely in America over the years, living in Down-East Maine for a period of time. More recently I re-visiting the Pacific West Coast while based out of Seattle, but I always seem to return to South East Asia.
  • I have started this Indiegogo campaign to raise money for the production of a fairly large number of archival quality prints, which I can exhibit at various galleries and other venues in Siem Reap, Bangkok, Singapore and hopefully soon back in the USA.
  • I am an old style photographer who processed his own film and produced his own prints in the darkroom, but I have kept up with the times and now can produce photographic prints using all the latest digital tools - from digital cameras, to computers, digital workflow software, and the latest generation of archival quality inkjet printers. All the prints that I am offering here will have been shot, processed and printed 100% by myself.

With your help I will hopefully be able to produce enough archival quality prints, to successfully exhibit first in Cambodia and then take my show on the road to galleries and exhibition spaces in other countries.

What We Need & What You Get

Funding is needed for the following:

  • To produce a large number of archival quality photographic prints.
  • Whatever amount of money is raised with this campaign, will first be used to produce and deliver the prints ordered, and then on producing more prints and securing exhibition spaces.
  • ••••••••••
  • Since this campaign is all about producing and exhibiting photographic prints of the incredible Angkor temples, we want to give you a chance to own some of our archival quality, signed and numbered prints.
  • For $15 - you get a postcard - printed and signed by George Mann
  • For $50 - you get five postcards - printed and signed by George Mann
  • For $100 - you get one A4 size print + a postcard
  • For $200 - you get one A3 size print + a postcard
  • For $250 - you get one each A4 & A3 size prints + a postcard
  • For $500 - you get two each A4 & A3 size prints + a postcard
  • For $1000 - you get two each A3 & A4 sized prints and a three day guided photo tour around the temples of Angkor (in Siem Reap, Cambodia) - with George Mann - air fare and accommodations not included + a bunch of postcards
  • All prints are unframed, signed and numbered by George Mann
  • The main reason we do not sell framed prints, is because the cost of shipping framed prints internationally would be prohibitive.
  • Shipping is not included in the price of the prints, we will need your mailing address and preferred method of shipping, to determine shipping cost.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially:

  • If you like this campaign, please tell your friends about it.
  • If you are interested in sponsoring an exhibition of The Temples of Angkor, or know someone who might be interested, please contact me.

Thank you very much, George Mann

story:
Short Summary

For anyone who lives in Canada or in the northern states or other contries, we all know that when winter hits, it hits hard and very cold. And I have found that people don't like to go out into this weather and freeze their butts off doing photography. Winter can last half a year so that's a lot of shooting I and people that want me to shoot them are out of.

I'm Nicholas Fischer and I started to get into photography 5 years ago and have been doing it on and off again since then. In November of 2011 I was asked to do a photo shoot for someone, and after doing it sparked my passion for photography was again. In the last year I have been taking photography very seriously. I have done many shoots including my first wedding, a grad, maternity, family and some model shoots.

And then winter hit all shoots dried up. I had 6 shoots planned just before the first snow fall. And I love to shoot outdoors and the people I have shot with do as well but I need an alternate soulution. And instead of renting an expensive studio and having to booking specific time, I have a little space to accomadate my needs and make my own little studio. This studio will be used all year round and I will let other people use the studio for their photography needs.

 

You can check out my Photography on my Flikr account http://www.flickr.com/photos/nicholasfischer/

 

What I Need & What You Get

I am seeking $1500 for my project. This will cover most of what I need to fully develop this poject. It will definitely give a kickstart to a great future of photography.

Things I will be getting with the money:

Paint

Wall repairs and modifications.

Back drop stand

Light mover rail system

Canon EF 50mm f/1.4 USM lens

Softbox light

Flood light

 

And here's what you get in return for helping fund this project:

You will recive high quality prints of some of the photo's I have taken over the years. You will get to choose between an 8x10 to 20x24 options for various sizes and quantities. And for the local people of Saskatchewan I am offering various photo shoots, from 1 session up to 7 sessions, unless you are planning on travelling to Saskatchewan then that would also work.

The Impact

Now by you helping fund this porject, you will be helping capture special moments in peoples lives as well as some of your own special moments. If I eventually go places with photography you will know that you had a hand in making that happen. And for those with the prints, you will have a nice story to tell people who enter your home.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you aren't able to donate any money, it's not the greatest time of the year right after Christmas but you can help share this to people you know. Fell free to share this on Facebook, Twitter and any other social media website you like. Thank you taking the time to look and to all those you contribute.

story:
Executive Summary:

 A 244 page fine art monograph, featuring Ethan Russell's photography, including his work with many musical legends including The Beatles, The Rolling Stones and The Who published for the first time in one beautifully printed volume. Preface by Ethan Russell. Introduction by Shannon Perich Photographic Curator for the Smithsonian National Museum of American History, and Preface by Neal Preston, Photographer.

The Project: History Lived

As I've engaged in building this campaign, the reality of what it signifies has grown. This is something we do, something we build together. There's something special about that, and I commit to trying to keeping the communications open as we progress.

This is my legacy project. I am a late in life father with a 15-year-old son, and in many ways this is for him.  It is my first and only fine art monograph. 

The pace and order of the book is an expression of what my life experience has been as seen through my photographs. It is a journey through ordinary and extraordinary moments that is specific to my life, but in truth, it’s one of exploration, surprise, love, and even some history, that many of us witnessed and know its uniqueness. These things I want to share with you and connect through them to find a bit of shared experience for those who were there and to open that up for those who were not able to be there. The Introduction by Shannon Perich, Photographic Curator for the Smithsonian National Museum of American History speaks eloquently to this.

My goal is to raise sufficient funds to print 500 books, and to offer rewards and incentives to support that goal. This campaign is only committed to printing 500 books, something I've done to keep the initial funding request down.

Supporters of this campaign should note my insistence on top quality reproduction, even if that keeps the production costs up. It is important to focus on the distinctiveness of this book. It is a "fine art monograph" as opposed to simply a book, and that means (to me at least) that the quality of the reproduction plays an essential role. It will be top tier. The book weighs over 5.5 lbs (the Deluxe Edition weighs 8 lbs). The monograph's dimensions are 14 x 10.25 inches (28 inches wide when open) and it will be 244 pages. Because I am sensitive to supporters about the costs, please know the $95 price (at level 2) for just the book and a card is based just on the cost of printing and estimated shipping.

I hope this commitment to quality brings satisfaction to the people who have always liked my work – to be able to see it finally presented simply and beautifully printed. 

I have worked hard to have the rewards and incentives seem appropriate for the level of donation. If you have any questions do not hesitate to contact me.

About the Journey

I was an accidental photographer. I was lucky. Of all my creative work it has been my photography which has brought the most joy to the most people.  While I have labored intensively on books where the story was the focus, I never really let my photographic work simply stand on its own. Now, paging through the prototype of the book, I find I am touched by the photographs gathered together without distraction, flowing page after page with simply a caption (although sometimes a lengthy one) as if the photographs were finally allowed to speak for themselves. 

This project has been iterating for many years. With the support and feedback of professional colleagues and kind friends, the layout of the book, the design and the essays have come together to bring us to the final stages of printing and publication.  I hope you will participate in making this book a reality. 

It is with these goals that I  enter into this Kickstarter project. 

BACKGROUND

I began my photographic career without formal training.  Asked to explain how I had any capacity to work as a photographer at all, I recalled a mental image of myself when I was around 11 standing in an orchard at my parents' ranch. I was a hunter - mostly for blue jays – using a small, 22-caliber single-shot rifle.    It was a solitary experience. I would wait quietly in the heat. There were only, maybe, ten trees, and they didn’t bear much fruit. But I would hide as best as I could, not moving a muscle, until a blue jay showed up. Then advancing slowly so I would not scare the bird, I would bring the gun to my shoulder, sight it, and carefully squeeze the trigger. Years later I identified this set of skills — an ability to scan a scene, to remain barely visible, to move quickly, focus, and then press a release steadily— as core skills for the kind of photographer I became, and at which I earned my living for years, a job I was never trained to do.

I got on a plane in 1967 from San Francisco to London in the height of British invasion fully expecting that when I emerged it would be into a mecca of music that would dwarf what was happening in San Francisco. This is not what I found. It was there, but it was barely visible in day to day London.  But with "more luck than any human being should be allowed to have" (The Daily Beast) I was introduced to Mick Jagger, then John Lennon, then The Rolling Stones and then The Beatles.  I took it from there.

When I think today about how my work might bring value, I believe this is the most significant: I didn’t change what was in front of the camera, and what was in front of the camera was monumental.  I photographed what was true. I was in extraordinary places, and I shot photographs that let people just be there. The moment is not about the photographer, the moment is about what you share.

I believe that my intuition about the music and the artists, for whom I felt enormous respect and admiration, comes through.  There is also an intimacy in much of the work that results from my invisibility, which grew from the considerable time I spent with them and the trust that came from that.  My photographs reveal, in a phrase I sometimes use, real moments with extraordinary people.  Those are what I would like to share with you.

BOOK SPECS

There will be two versions of the book the Regular Edition (expected price: $95) and the Deluxe Limited Edition (expected price: $450.) All copies given to backers of this Kickstarter project will be from the First Edition printing of the book, which I will oversee.

Note: there will be an additional publication starting at level 4: a separately bound  (and shipped) approximately 45 page book "The Inside Story." This will provide even more background on the images in the book, where they were taken, the circumstances, technical information (camera, lens, film, lighting rig, etc.)  This is not expected to be available  with the commercial version of the book.

Please also note: Those interested should take advantage of this Special First Printing of the Deluxe Edition because it’s likely that after the Kickstarter campaign is over the Deluxe Edition of the book may not be available, or, if available, may be more expensive.

NEW PERK

Just added as a thank-you to all who have already pledged and for all who pledge going forward at any level that includes a book (Regular or Deluxe) a signed and personalized printed triptych of me shooting The Beatles, The Rolling Stones & The Who, That is a calling card of my work as a photographer and it occurred to me that it would be nice for those helping make this campaign happen to have a personal thank-you. See below. 

 

THE REGULAR EDITION

 

THE DELUXE LIMITED EDITION

 

PERKS

 THE INSIDE STORY 

"The Inside Story,"  is a separately bound (and shipped) estimated 45 page book, which will give even more background about the images in the book, where they were taken, the circumstances, technical information (camera, lens, film, lighting rig, etc.) 

 

DELUXE EDITION 8x10 print choices 

Five signed, archival individually printed choices below from which to select one (or two, depending on level) for inclusion with DELUXE EDITION and  Clamshell.

 

The prints above and all signed archival prints in this campaign, regardless of size, are museum quality. They are the exact quality as those sold from my website, the galleries that carry my work or the museums that collect my work. The limited edition prints will be numbered taken from my official editions. They are substantially reduced in price in the context of this campaign, which is why each image offered is listed separately, and the number available for sale is limited.

 

$1100 or more.  16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, LIMITED EDITION ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT Choose from one of the two below. (Reward limit 15 of each).

 

$1200 or more. 16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT "MICK JAGGER 'LIPS' 1972.  Limit 1.

 Level 10:  $1,400 or more. 16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT "WHO'S NEXT, ENGLAND 1971." Limit 4.

$1600 or more. 16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT "JOHN LENNON LISTENING TO THE WHITE ALBUM LONDON 1968" Limit 1

$1,675 or more 16X20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT  of "KEITH RICHARDS WITH JACK AND COORS 1972" (Limit 3)

Note: 24x35 is a European size that I think bears calling out. I love it because when framed with a reasonable matte it is a wonderful display size, not so big that it overtakes everything, but big enough to really be impressive. 

Keith Richards "Purple" was chosen as one of the few actual prints on display in the Rolling Stones "Exhibitionism" (I was told.) Most of the images in the display were digital. It was in the "Fashion" section.

"We have scoured hundreds of images of Jerry Lee and think that yours is by far the most riveting and gorgeous and unique...I can’t get over this photo--it is sort of haunting and cool and odd, like a David Lynch movie...It is one of the snazziest, hottest, most beguiling music portraits ever.”  OXFORD AMERICAN MAGAZINE

ARTISTS, PLACES & EVENTS INCLUDED IN BOOK (listed individually and as bands, in order of appearance)

  •  Harbour Island, Bahamas 
  •  Pebble Beach California 
  •  Barbara Migdal 
  •  Oakland, California 
  •  Blue Cheer San Francisco 
  • London, UK 
  •  Hyde Park, UK 
  •  Mick Jagger 
  •  Yoko Ono 
  •  John Lennon 
  •  Benny Goodman 
  •  Frank Zappa 
  •  Grace Slick 
  •  Stevie Winwood 
  •  Leopold Stakowski 
  •  Charlie Watts 
  •  Keith Richards 
  •  The Rolling Stones 
  •  Brian Jones 
  •  Jean Luc Godard 
  •  Jim Morrison 
  •  Cream 
  • The Rolling Stones "You Can't Always Get What You Want"
  •  Janis Joplin 
  • The Rolling Stones Rock and Roll Circus
  •  Dirty Mac - Eric Clapton, John Lennon, Keith Richards & Mitch Mitchell
  • The Beatles - Let It Be
  • Paul McCartney 
  •  Ringo Starr 
  •  George Harrison 
  • The Beatles On the Roof
  • The Rolling Stones 1969 tour
  •  BB King 
  •  Chuck Berry 
  •  The Who - Who's Next
  • The Rolling Stones 1972 Tour
  •  Annie Leibovitz 
  •  Robert Frank 
  •  Terry Southern 
  •  Pete Townshend 
  •  Roger Daltrey 
  •  Carlos Santana 
  •  Rita Coolidge 
  •  James Taylor 
  •  The Eagles 
  • The Who - Quadrophenia
  •  Glyn Johns 
  •  Boz Scaggs 
  •  Jerry Lee Lewis 
  •  Linda Ronstadt 
  •  John Hiatt

  •  Dave Mason 
  •  Greece 
  •  Mendocino 

 

* Please note: once the Kickstarter project is complete, we will be contacting you to confirm your choices, when applicable, so stay tuned.

Keith Richards "Patience Please 1972" (8x10 choice)Linda Ronstadt "Hasten Down the Wind" (8x10 choice)John Lennon London 1968 (8x10 choice)8x10 Janis Joplin Royal Albert Hall 1969 (8x10 choice)The Rolling Stones Onstage 1969 (8x10 choice) The prints above and all signed archival prints in this campaign, regardless of size, are museum quality. They are the exact quality as those sold from my website, the galleries that carry my work or the museums that collect my work. The limited edition prints will be numbered taken from my official editions. They are substantially reduced in price in the context of this campaign, which is why each image offered is listed separately, and the number available for sale is limited. $1100 or more.  16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, LIMITED EDITION ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT Choose from one of the two below. (Reward limit 15 of each).The Rolling Stones "How Long Will They Last, 1969" Limit 9 (16x20 choice)The Who In Rehearsal 1973 (16x20 choice) $1200 or more. 16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT "MICK JAGGER 'LIPS' 1972.  Limit 1.Mick Jagger "Lips" 1972. Signed, limited edition, digital archival print. Limit 4 (16x20 choice) Level 10:  $1,400 or more. 16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT "WHO'S NEXT, ENGLAND 1971." Limit 4. $1600 or more. 16x20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT "JOHN LENNON LISTENING TO THE WHITE ALBUM LONDON 1968" Limit 1John Lennon Listening to the White Album 1968. Signed, limited edition, digital archival print. Limit 1
 $1,675 or more 16X20 LIMITED EDITION, SIGNED, ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT  of "KEITH RICHARDS WITH JACK AND COORS 1972" (Limit 3)"Keith Richards with Jack and Coors 1972" (16x20 choice) Limit 2
 
Level 13B: $4,000 or more. 24X35 SIGNED LIMITED EDITION ARCHIVAL FINE ART PRINT. CHOOSE FROM ONE OF THE FIVE BELOW.  IN ADDITION,  A SIGNED 8X10 PRINT OF YOUR CHOOSING FROM ANYTHING OFFERED IN THIS CAMPAIGN.   (Limit 5. It could be all one print or various but if 5 24x35 prints are taken then the reward is fulfilled).Note: 24x35 is a European size that I think bears calling out. I love it because when framed with a reasonable matte it is a wonderful display size, not so big that it overtakes everything, but big enough to really be impressive. Mick Jagger and Chuck Berry 1969 (24x35 choice)Keith Richards with Jack and Coors 1972 (24x35 choice).24x35 Signed, Limited Edition, Digital Archival Print, Keith Richards "Purple" 1969 (24x35 choice)Keith Richards "Purple" was chosen as one of the few actual prints on display in the Rolling Stones "Exhibitionism" (I was told.) Most of the images in the display were digital. It was in the "Fashion" section.24x35 Signed, limited edition archival print. "The Rolling Stones On Stage 1972." (24x35 choice)24x35 Jerry Lee Lewis "Spotlight" 1975 (24x35 choice)
 "We have scoured hundreds of images of Jerry Lee and think that yours is by far the most riveting and gorgeous and unique...I can’t get over this photo--it is sort of haunting and cool and odd, like a David Lynch movie...It is one of the snazziest, hottest, most beguiling music portraits ever.”  OXFORD AMERICAN MAGAZINELinda Ronstadt "Hasten Down the Wind" Malibu 1975 (24x35 choice)

story:
Limited Time Offer

Hi there; it's Noel again.

Thanks to your investments in my Beyond Borders: Euro Trip project, my mission to gather print-worthy photos from Europe was a roaring success. I've extended the opportunity to claim these limited addition prints by one week, so claim them while you can.

Check out some samples I got below:

France

After nearly a decade of planning, patience, and providence, I captured the sunset shot of Normandy's Mont Saint Michel I'd always yearned to grab.

Paris and the smaller towns were also very generous to me.


Spain

Not only did I document the famous San Fermin Festival in Pamplona, I actually ran with the bulls, myself.


Ireland

I devoted ten days to the green fields, cobblestone streets, and medieval ruins of the Emerald Isle. These photos are as memorable as my misadventures with the locals.


Belgium

30 hours in Bruges yielded a special crop of engaging street photos and enchanting long exposures for all the street and cityscape photography fans out there.


To Sum it All Up

Here's the deal: Backers just like you sent me to Europe and I did my part to bring you some sweet art. Now for your part. You claim the perks and I'll make good on the goods.

Just ask the satisfied contributors of my last project ... unless you are one of them.

As you read this, I'm going through the monumental task of sorting through over 5,000 shots and narrowing it down to between 50-100 of the very best images for you to choose from.

Perks

Prints

Available in Luster Paper, Metal, and Canvas in a variety of sizes.

8x12" Luster Print Example

12x18" Metal Print Example

24x36" Canvas Print Example

I'll send you a link to a contributors-only gallery on my website where you'll pick the shot you want and email me your selection. I'll hand-inspect each print, sign the back, and ship it to you.

Calendars

Available in Large Wall Size (12x18") and Small Desktop Size (5.43x12").

Large Wall 2017 Calendar Example

I'll pick my 13 favorite shots that cover the whole trip and design the layout. I'll hand-inspect each calendar, sign it, and ship it to you. This was the crowd favorite last year.

Photo Books

10.5x12" Large Photo Book Example

I design all my own photo books, consisting of my hand-selected best shots and stories that will accompany them. I'll hand-inspect each copy, sign it, and ship it to you.

Koozies

It'll keep your 12 oz beer or beverage ice cold for the journey ahead and comes with the Beyond Borders Logo emblazoned across it.

"Beyond Borders" Original Song

You can preview the original song I co-wrote with fellow Louisiana native Levi Petree at: soundcloud.com/user891480713/beyondborders


TL;DR:

Take advantage of this pre-sale or cry yourself to sleep. It's your call.

story:
About the Book

It is impossible to visit Yangon and not be enchanted by the relics of old Rangoon evident everywhere in the crumbling city. These 'Relics of Rangoon' are more than just beautiful buildings. These are the storied past and future promise of a city that was once the greatest international trading port in the world, second only to New York. 

But a lack of documentation on the city's multitude of built heritage and a lack of political will is seeing these gorgeous landmarks - icons of old Rangoon's former glory days - disappear under the wrecking ball of developers looking to put up quick, cheap condo constructions. 

Relics of Rangoon for the first time profiles through in depth research and photography the inside and out of more than 200 of the city's architectural gems.

Making the publication of Relics of Rangoon a reality will help to positively influence the conservation conversation in Yangon and to embed the importance of built heritage in the public's eye.  

The book will be the culmination of over two years of research with a team of more than eight researchers, over 8,000 photographs, hundreds of hours of interviews with custodians, trustees, government officials, custodians, architects and conservation experts, and documentation research in the Myanmar National Archives. 

What We Need & What You Get

Relics is seeking initial funding of US$10,000 to help publish, distribute and cover the costs for the first edition of the book, which are now being printed.

This money will go toward direct printing costs, which are in excess of $25,000, marketing and logistics for putting the book, its data and research in front of as many people as possible. 

The book will retail at USD 75.00 once published, so with a target contribution of USD 60.00 you will have a first edition of the hardcover book, which stands at just under 400 pages of high definition photographs and research text. Other great options are also available for those with any budget!

First editions will go out to backers at the end of May!


The Conservation Conversation

Myanmar has been undergoing a period of rapid change. It has the fastest growing economy of any of its Southeast Asian neighbors and stands with the resources and potential to become the region's power, natural resources and manufacturing leader. 

But in the face of such a great pace of modernity, the nation formerly known as Burma is risking the loss of its culture, identity and very history. In Yangon, the country's commercial capital, the buildings tell stories of a multi-racial, multi-religious past where trade, enterprise and innovation boomed. Architects from Scotland to Iran, Britain to Pakistan built monuments to the hopes and dreams of a city that would become a world leader. These buildings speak not just of the past, but of the future potential for a country that suffered for too long at the hands of junta dictators. 

The 'conservation conversation' is a pressing on in Myanmar, especially in Yangon. Relics of Rangoon has been meticulously researched to provide for the first time the most comprehensive look at the city's built past, and how it shines a light on future potential. 

Read some of Phil's past reporting on the issues here:

http://www.bbc.com/news/business-31146066

http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/04/strangled-traffic-yangon-201441082132744464.html

http://www.nationmultimedia.com/life/Creative-spaces-unsavoury-places-30234492.html

http://www.bangkokpost.com/archive/yangon-s-new-look/420608

http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/tourism/492150/history-needs-help

Reviews for Relics of Rangoon

Relics is a self-published project that has been endorsed by the YCDC, British Council, French Institute, Indian Embassy and more. 

PRAISE FOR RELICS OF RANGOON

"There were not many upsides to come out of Myanmar's decades of dictatorship, and none can compensate for the damage wrought upon the country. But one 'good thing' that did, and that today we can even see and feel, is the serendipitous fact that the lack of economic progress across these years saved the exquisite ancient structures and colonial buildings of Rangoon, Myanmar's commercial, cultural and political heart, from the wrecking ball. This may not last for long. Newly opened to the world, Rangoon's singular charm as simultaneously a metropolis of struggle in the vibrant present and oasis of things past, is driving a feverish reconstruction. Much of this is good and unavoidable, some of it is destructive and short-sighted, all of it will change Rangoon forever.

Relics of Rangoon is a magnificent tribute to this jewel of a city, past, present and future. The product of the loving eyes, dedication, and prolonged exertions of a team led by Philip Heijmans, Relics of Rangoon could not have been better nor relevantly timed. Beautifully photographed, handsomely produced, and insightfully written, Relics of Rangoon captures a passing moment of remembrance, deliverance and great hope. This book is a monument to be treasured."

Sean Turnell, Associate Professor, Department of Economics at Macquarie University and Economic Advisor to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy Party.

“This beautiful book will be an eye-opener. Rangoon grew into a great trading city, on the banks of the Irrawaddy river and in sight of the golden Shwedagon, in the 19th and early 20thCs. As the city now emerges from a period of hibernation, the quality and extent of its colonial architecture – much of created by fellow Scots – becomes more and more a revelation. The excellence of Philip Heijman’s photographs and his concise but thoroughly researched accounts will appeal to tourists and scholars alike. Rangoon was, for me, ‘love at first sight’ and I will treasure Philip’s book.”

Dr James Simpson OBE FRIAS, Simpson & Brown Architects:

Other Ways You Can Help

Help Relics of Rangoon by sharing this page with your networks using the sharing icons here! 

Also check us out on our website at www.relicsofrangoon.com and on Facebook, https://www.facebook.com/relicsofrangoon/.

Thank you for your support and pre-order your copy of Relics of Rangoon today!!

story:
Light Cycles

My name is JP Trostle — I’m an artist and graphic designer living in Durham, North Carolina.

One day, while following a happy accident down the rabbit hole, I discovered a world of light and motion that exists only inside the camera. My abstract images explore texture and movement through an unconventional use of digital photography, reshaping familiar locations into ethereal landscapes and photon waves.

For 12 years I have been pushing the limits of my cameras and iPhones, and exhibited these "light cycles" in more than a half dozen shows in Durham, Raleigh, Chapel Hill, and beyond. 

Recently, the Durham Arts Council contacted me about showing my work in the downtown Convention Center. They wanted a dozen big new pieces to float in the central conduit running between the historic Carolina Theater and conference center — and they would like to open the exhibit in January 2020.

This only gives me a few weeks to prep, print and hang this show.

This is my most ambitious presentation of the series to date. Because I have less than two months to pull the exhibit together, I am turning to you for assistance in launching this project. 

The Goal

Printing and hanging photography is expensive. I will need at least $1500 to create and frame the 12 images that I've selected for "Quantum Flux." To raise those funds, I will be offering backers cards, calendars and prints of my other work, and pieces from my earlier exhibits "Lights Cycles" and "Luminous Creatures." Some of the photographs are unique and will never be reproduced again.

The show is happening no matter what: this is the single largest exhibit space in the city,  and a once in a career opportunity, so — any amount you can pledge will go towards printing costs.

As far as quality goes, I will be working with Roylee Duvall at Through This Lens, an exceptional photo gallery and production shop here in downtown Durham. Roylee is THE go to for professional photographers in town.

Risks & Challenges

I've staged 3 solo shows of this series at the Atomic Fern Social Club in Durham (at left), and been part of 5 juried group exhibits in North Carolina and Virginia. While I've never worked at this scale (30" x 40"), Roylee has produced massive prints for museums so I have the utmost confidence we can produce these very large photos for the show. 

My main challenge will be raising the funds for this exhibit in a short period of time. Any support you can give, or help in sharing this campaign, will be most appreciated.

Quantum Flux opens January 14, 2020.

story:
In 2005, Nick Danziger began to create an archive of photographs documenting the lives of women and children in eight of the world's poorest countries. He returned five years later, and again in 2015. Had the United Nation’s millennium development goals made a difference to their lives?

The stories he tells  - in pictures and words - are unforgettable and have created a unique document, one that reveals the uncomfortable truths of a globalised planet. It is full of hope, sadness, pain, anger and beauty.

 

Some of the women and children Nick followed died through sickness and poverty. One has become the most successful entrepreneur her African border town has ever known. Another – who once dreamed of becoming a banker – is now a gang member in the world’s murder capital. Yet another has confronted conformists and successfully changed his gender.

The book will stand as a permanent record of their courage and humanity, but also as a reminder that much work still needs to be done if these goals (now re-branded as Sustainable Development Goals) are ever to be met. Too many people in India, Cambodia, Zambia, Uganda, Niger, Honduras, Bolivia and Armenia are still living in extreme poverty, without access to the health and education the goals were supposed to deliver.

Over the past two years, the book has grown in scale and complexity. Despite having raised over £30,000, we still need to raise another £10,000 to make it into  the book that Nick's work deserves.

If we do – with your help - it will arrive in April 2019.

 

 

Specification

The book is set to be a memorable example of fine printing and contemporary book art. 

It will be large format (324 x 243mm), 320 pp linen-bound hardcover, printed tritone using a special selection of black and grey premium inks, on Garda Premium 160 gsm paper, with a French-folded jacket.

The quality of reproduction is second to none: the designer (Mark Thomson) and printer (De Keure) have already won numerous awards and accolades for their work on Danziger’s books.

The type is Lexicon by Bram de Does, hailed variously as ‘the world’s most expensive typeface’ and one of the greatest type designs ever.

Another – who once dreamed of becoming a banker – is now a gang member in the world’s murder capital. Yet another has confronted conformists and successfully changed his gender.The book will stand as a permanent record of their courage and humanity, but also as a reminder that much work still needs to be done if these goals (now re-branded as Sustainable Development Goals) are ever to be met. Too many people in India, Cambodia, Zambia, Uganda, Niger, Honduras, Bolivia and Armenia are still living in extreme poverty, without access to the health and education the goals were supposed to deliver.Over the past two years, the book has grown in scale and complexity. Despite having raised over £30,000, we still need to raise another £10,000 to make it into  the book that Nick's work deserves.If we do – with your help - it will arrive in April 2019.  SpecificationThe book is set to be a memorable example of fine printing and contemporary book art. It will be large format (324 x 243mm), 320 pp linen-bound hardcover, printed tritone using a special selection of black and grey premium inks, on Garda Premium 160 gsm paper, with a French-folded jacket.The quality of reproduction is second to none: the designer (Mark Thomson) and printer (De Keure) have already won numerous awards and accolades for their work on Danziger’s books.The type is Lexicon by Bram de Does, hailed variously as ‘the world’s most expensive typeface’ and one of the greatest type designs ever.

story:
Help us found this project  with a free exhibition entry and a photo book. 


WHAT MY PROJECT IS ABOUT.

This project consist of two themes: Documentary and Conceptual photography. 

 Documentary - reflects the simple peasant life in rural Moldova and the very special atmosphere in the Moldavian countryside landscape. 

Conceptual - is a series of photographs that reflect certain emotions and moods. Also in this series predominate nude photography. I tried to show more the sensual look and women's femininity.  

Beside exhibition, will be printed a photo book that will contains all photographs from the exhibition, and a series of photos taken in Lithuania, about rural life of this country.  

One of the purpose of the book is to share to people the difference of living and nature beauty of these two countries. Moldova and Lithuania.

 

The opening will take place at the

House of National Comunities, in Vilnius - Lithuania

Raugyklos street - 25

2012 august 9th at 6 p.m

 


ABOUT ME.

I was born on February 22, 1987 in Moldova. I graduated high school "Ciprian Porumbescu" as a drummer. After 12 years of music I went to the Academy of Music, Theater and Fine arts, specialty film directing and editing. In this four years of education, three of them were about photography. Professor of photography was Nicolae Pojoga, a very great teacher and photographer which gave us some wonderful knowledge about photography. I love working with film, therefore all my photographs were taken on medium format 6x6 film.    

Awards:

  • — 1s place at the photography contest "Beyond words" organized by the "Punkt" magazine 2009
  • — 2d place at the photography contest "The historic center of Chisinau in the vision of young amateur photography" 2011
  • — Winner in the category "Fine Art Nude" at 1x Photo Awards 2011



FOR  WHAT  WEE NEED THE MONEY.

  • First of all the most of the money will go to prints for exhibitions. This includes  printing, mounting and installation of the work.  

  • For printed photo book and postcards 

     

  • For purchasing, developing and scanning film.

     

Thank you so much for taking a look at my project and I hope that it inspires you to pledge your support to me and this exhibition and photo book.  

If you believe, as we do, that this project has great worth, please help us spread the word!  Share with your friends and family  Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Short Summary

I'm Rosa Maria from Detroit, Michigan. I graduated from Grand Valley State University with a degree in photography. I'm primarily focused on documentary photography. I love telling stories from ordinary people around the city that in reality, usually turn out to be extraordinary people. 

This campaign is to help me take a once in a life time work shop with a legendary photographer! Mary Ellen Mark is an amazing photographer who has accomplished so

much in the field of photography, including winning three J.F.K Journalism Awards and having 16 collections of her work shown worldwide. She is a true role model and someone who has become a staple in documentary photography. Here is her website for more information: http://www.maryellenmark.com/

Your contribution will help me take a 10 day work shop in Oaxaca, Mexico with Mary Ellen Mark. This is an amazing opportunity that will help expand my work, both personally and professionally.If you had the opportunity to work and learn from the person YOU most admire in the art world, wouldn't you try to everything to try to make it happen? The work shop is in March and with such a time crunch, I am unable to save up enough money on my own. So, I am asking for your help...........

Help become part of making one of my dreams come true. 

What am I asking for?

The workshop itself cost $2,700.00, not including hotel or the roundtrip flight. I am trying to at least get the cost of the workshop, which is a big chunk of the cost. Any contribution helps and is GREATLY appreciated. If my goal is not reached, the funds

I do raise will be used to create a complete body of work about an aspect of Detroit. Your contribution will not be wasted. 

If you have read all of my terrible writing above, thank you. The fact that you are even reading this is amazing and I appreciate it. If you contribute, words will not be able to express my eternal gratitude. 

Interested in seeing my current work? Here is a link to my website: rosamariazamarron.com

story:
About Me

Hi, my name is Neil Barr and 12 months ago I picked up my first DSLR camera. With no prior training or experience, within 4 weeks I had taken shots that won me the Scotland Magazine Photo Challenge 2015 and gained Highly Commended in the first Scottish Landscape Photographer of the Year competition.

I've since gone on to gain other awards including Commended in the prestigious UK Landscape Photographer of the Year 2015 competition.

A graduate of Gray's School of Art in Aberdeen, I've spent the past 20 years running a successful web design business. I eventually sold up (in a deal that went flat) due to ill health and stress.  I shortly thereafter took up photography as a hobby, but also as therapy in my battle with anxiety. 20 years of daily stress had taken its toll.

I quickly found out that it is only when out in the landscape taking photographs (often camping out at the top of mountains for days) that I can escape the everyday problems. The freedom and joy I feel when watching the light move across the landscape along with our wonderful unpredictable Scottish weather is something I wish to get across in the finished art works.

I discovered within me a talent I didn't know existed and a vocation that I dearly want to continue with. I'll shortly be hosting my first solo exhibition as a landscape photographer at the Veneer Gallery, Glasgow in February 2016.

I need your help to allow me to keep producing work.

What I Need & What You Get

After nearly 60,000 shots and 30,000 miles travelled in just a year, my poor camera equipment is at deaths door. The mixture of shooting seascapes in storms, or standing up mountains in the pouring rain means my gear (as we say in Scotland), is "gubbed"!

In order to keep producing work up to the exhibition which will hopefully kick start my career as a photographer, I need to replace some of my equipment, especially my Canon 6D camera, along with damaged filters.

No camera, means no new photography. Unfortunately, losing my business left me with no other income and 30,000 miles of travel over the past year has severely dwindled my funds. The cost of putting on the exhibition (funded entirely by myself) will run in to the thousands.

Every pound raised will go towards new equipment and in return, every contributor will get;

  • For £20 (+ shipping) - signed A4 signed print from my portfolio & invite to exhibition preview.
  • For £40 (+ shipping) - signed A3 signed print from my portfolio & invite to exhibition preview.
  • For £60 (+ shipping) - signed A2 signed print from my portfolio & invite to exhibition preview.
  • For £80 - half days 1-2-1 tuition for one person, within 50 mile radius of Glasgow & invite to exhibition preview.
  • For £120 - full days 1-2-1 tuition for one person, within 50 mile radius of Glasgow & invite to exhibition preview.
All prints will be hand signed and printed on Epson Premium Luster Photo Paper with Ultra Chrome K3 Inks and delivered in time for Christmas. Contributors can select from any photograph in my portfolio on www.neilbarr.co.uk. Further details on tuition (with standard prices) on my site - www.neilbarr.co.uk/121-photography-tuition

Please have a look at the gallery attached to this campaign or my work on www.neilbarr.co.uk to see what I have produced so far. I'll email every contributor personally after the campaign to arrange selection and printing of your prints or to arrange the 1-2-1 tuition.

The Impact

I am currently in discussions with other galleries across Scotland about follow up exhibitions. A successful run at the Veneer Gallery will boost my chances of more exhibitions.

This exhibition will be a major step in my dream for a long sustainable career in landscape photography and ultimately a route to recovery. It will allow me to fund new work, reach an audience I couldn’t otherwise reach and for the first time, show the quality of my work in the manner it was always meant to be seen.

Challenges

Landscape photography is often seen as the 'poor man' of the art world. It can be challenging to produce and make your mark in it when there are so many doing it these days.

I hope my work speaks for itself. I am improving every day, but only with your help can I have any hope of continuing down this road. Success will mean even better work in the future and hopefully the funds to keep producing it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot assist with a contribution, please have a look at my portfolio and spread the word, or even buy a small print or two. Please use the share tools to let your friends and family know about my campaign.

Thanks for reading,

Neil Barr

story:
The photography seniors at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) have been working over the past three years to delve into the creative and what it means to be an artist. The eleven of us have grown together as peers to create unique works that have examined various themes that are explored in photography. Now we are preparing to complete our studies and present our BFA Photography Exhibition.

But we need your help! For us to have a successful event, we must find a proper venue and transform it into a professional gallery. Any amount you can donate will help us work towards our goal of hosting a stellar show and would be greatly appreciated. Please, support us in our efforts to put on a fantastic show. 

Thank you, so much!

The 2013 Photography Seniors: Animah Boakye, Lindsay Davis, Gino Baileau, Harrison Hakes, Brittany Keating, John-Jack Kendall, Kendall McCaugherty, John Menchaca, Erin Randle, Alejandra Rodriguez, and Samantha Serrano

Funds that we receive will go to...

...renting a space for the show, refreshments, buying lights, paint, tools for hanging, frames, printing costs, and advertising are just a few supplies needed for a great event. After securing supplies we must go about arranging, hanging, and setting up for the exhibition. There will be travel to and from the space, many hours spent hanging things, hours putting up flyers around campus and the local community, and realizing we didn't get enough supplies and having to get more.

If you can't contribute, spread the word! Post a link to our fundraiser on Facebook! Tweet it! Instagram a handwritten note! :D Get the word out to anybody who can help! Every dollar matters!

Thanks again!

 

UPDATES SINCE STARTING THE CAMPAIGN:

We were featured on the front page of the Daily Illini: http://issuu.com/thedailyillini/docs/di12072012/1

story:
Me and my problem!

Hello!
My name is Eleonora, I'm 32 years old. I'm from Italy. I'm a computer programmer, but I really love art in all its forms, I love painting, drawing and my biggest passion is photography.
On October 2011, I went to work in Joensuu, in the north of Finland. It 'was a wonderful experience although a little hard for me. I was born in Sicily, always warm temperatures and lots of sun. Joensuu is a city pretty, but cold and winter is too dark. I do not know if these conditions have contributed to my disease.
In December 2011, after a heavy bleeding from my nose, I started to not see well.
 
Progressively my eyesight has deteriorated and I had some severe headaches for more than six months.
Back in Bologna I did several tests (MRI and CAT scan) and I discovered a small tumor (thankfully benign) inside my head, the sphenoid.

In July 2012, I removed the tumor, and my vision has continued to deteriorate. I did many medical tests; Italian health service provides free medical care but I had to pay a lot of expenses to avoid long waits (currently I spent about 2000 €).
 
I was very worried and scared, monocular loss of vision is a symptom of multiple sclerosis. So I did other diagnostic neurological and ophthalmological test, my doctors have diagnosed optic neuritis.

My view is a disaster, I'm a programmer and you can imagine the hard work that I do every day to work. I loved to read so much, but now after a few rows I have severe nausea. Fortunately, the left eye (although it has some symptom of optic neuritis) works quite well.

There is no cure for this disease, I can only take vitamins and alpha lipoic acid and hope that in one year or two I will be able to see better. I see all blurry, colors appear washed out and sometimes all the same, I do not recognize more details. And when I look the light, it seems to take a punch in the face. Sometimes, it is very painful! :-(


I added some of my photos of how I see now.

 

My project, my dreams and my idea?

With the fear that my vision degenerates and with the hope that it will come back as before, I have a wish! I want to tell the 2013 through photography! I love the portraits! I would take a picture of everyone I meet and keep their faces, eyes and smiles in one click.

I ask to help me to improve my camera equipment, I have a nikon D90 camera with two lens. I'd like buy a lens for macro protography, one for portraits, a good flash, a tripod and some lights. It would be nice to do a photography course to improve my technique!

During this campaign, I will publish some of my photos and I will keep you updated about my health.  May be on day, I will do a little exhibition or a book! :-)

 

 

Thanks for help me to realize my dreams and I hope you can realize your dreams!

Eleonora
